title: The sightless philanthropist who gave blind veterans hope
story: A statue of seven blinded soldiers was unveiled outside of Manchester Piccadilly train station today (Image: Terry Waller Alamy Live News)First deployed by the Germans in the Battle of Ypres in 1915, this chilling new type of chemical warfare reached its deadliest form through the use of mustard gas from 1917.A vivid description of its impact was left by the Great War poet Wilfred Owen, who wrote of soldiers, knock-kneed, coughing like hags and of blood come gurgling from the froth-corrupted lungs. Altogether, there were 188,000 British Army casualties from gas attacks during the war.Blindness, temporary or permanent, was a frequent consequence, adding to the savage toll on men's vision exacted by bullets and shells.                Father of the Blind &ndash A Portrait of Sir Arthur Pearson                109,000 call for Tommies tax breakIn the four years of the struggle, 31,000 British soldiers were discharged with damaged or defective eyesight caused by war. Of this total, more than 2,000 were fully blind.At first there was only limited support for these wounded heroes, not least because the welfare state was in its infancy and rehabilitation services were woefully inadequate for the scale of the problem.It was to meet the pressing needs of the blinded ex-servicemen that in 1915 the St Dunstan's charity was established by Sir Arthur Pearson, the philanthropist and press magnate who had founded the  at the beginning of the century.HARROWING:John Singer Sargent's painting Gassed is based on all too common scenes from the Great War (Image: IWMGetty Images)The organisation took its name from St Dunstan's Lodge in Regent's Park, London, where its first headquarters was based. Due to Sir Arthur's determination to focus on practical help, veterans were given a crash course in Braille and were taught a number of trades, including shorthand, carpentry, massage, boot repair and telephony so they were better equipped for the outside world.From these beginnings, the charity flourished. Renamed Blind Veterans UK in 2012, its pioneering work now promotes independence and a better quality of life for 4,700 visually impaired ex-services personnel, no matter what the cause of their blindness.One former soldier who profoundly appreciates its specialist services and encouragement is Simon Brown. As a corporal in the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, he was on a tour of duty in Iraq when he was shot in the face by a sniper in 2006.He awoke from a coma 17 days later in a Birmingham hospital to be told that his left eye had been destroyed and there was little hope for his right. Yet, with the help of the charity, he rebuilt his life and went on to work in the voluntary sector.I learnt to accept my sight loss and with the support of Blind Veterans UK, I stopped being a victim and became a survivor, he says.As the centenary of the end of the First World War approaches, the story of the charity resonates all the more powerfully because yesterday, at Piccadilly station in Manchester, a magnificent bronze statue was unveiled by the Countess of Wessex as a tribute to its achievements.The Manchester statue was unveiled by the Countess of Wessex, here with a veteran (Image: CH)Entitled Victory Over Blindness, one of Sir Arthur's mottoes, this superbly crafted sculpture depicts seven blind soldiers marching forward, each one with a hand on the shoulder of the comrade in front.The striking image has its inspiration in the iconic painting Gassed, by the American artist John Singer Sargent, who in 1918 had witnessed a line of British soldiers at a dressing station in northern France, waiting for treatment after they had been blinded by mustard gas.On first viewing Sargent's huge picture, which was 21ft long, Winston Churchill commented on its brilliant genius and painful significance.Chemical Warfare in the 20th century: British troops blinded by tear gas (Image: IWMGetty Images)Both the location and the sculptor of the Victory statue are deeply linked to the cause of the charity.Manchester Piccadilly was chosen as the site because an unceasing flood of wounded British soldiers passed through the station during the First World War, many of them on their way to a convalescent centre at nearby Heaton Park.The creator of the monument, Johanna Domke-Guyot, was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1994 and, as a result, has not only blurred vision but also little feeling in her hands.It was like art therapy for me, she says of her epic work, which she began in 2011. The time I've had with these seven figures over these years and seeing them come to life has been really amazing.Express founder Sir Arthur Pearson (Image: Ernest H. MillsGetty Images)Indeed, the whole saga of the statue is up-lifting. One of the driving forces behind the project is Blind Veterans trustee Barry Coupe, whose father Des lost his eyesight while fighting in 1943.At the time Des was just 20, an engineer and engaged to be married. But he did not allow his disability to wreck his life. With the backing of St Dunstan's and his own gutsy determination, he qualified as a physiotherapist, started a family and set up a private practice so successful that his services were used by major football clubs such as Liverpool and Preston North End.If it had not been for St Dunstan's, my father would not have achieved what he did, Barry told me.The life of the St Dunstan's founder is just as inspirational. The son of a clergyman, Sir Arthur used his dynamism and gift for innovation to make his fortune in the press, first through a number of periodicals and then, in 1900, through his establishment of the .It was an immediate hit with the public, partly because it was the first national newspaper to carry news rather than adverts on its front page.But amid all this success there was a dark shadow looming over Sir Arthur's life. Because of the onset of glaucoma he began to lose his vision. By 1913 he was completely blind and forced to sell all his press interests.Yet without any trace of self-pity, he channelled his colossal energies into campaigning for those like himself. For such a man, difficulties were positively attractive and the worst misfortune could have no terror, wrote his biographer.The statue in Manchester (Image: Terry Waller Alamy Live News)St Dunstan's was his crowning triumph but he also set up the Greater London Fund For The Blind, served as president of what is now the Royal National Institute Of Blind People, and published Braille books.When he died in 1921 aged 55, having drowned in his bath after accidentally knocking himself unconscious, more than 1,800 St Dunstaners attended his funeral, a reflection of the huge affection in which he was held.His courageous spirit lives on through figures such as Ken Facal, who was blinded by an improvised explosive device while on foot patrol in Helmand, Afghanistan, in 2010, but now, thanks to skills training from the charity, works as a fitness instructor.And through 96-year-old Peter Van Zeller, a D-Day veteran who has lost his sight due to glaucoma. Peter's own father Thomas was supported by St Dunstan's after he suffered terrible facial injuries when his tank was blown up on the Western Front during the First World War.I may be 96 but thanks to the charity I'm fit, active and enjoy lots of hobbies in spite of my sight loss. Without them, I don't know where I'd be, Peter said.Today's unveiling of the Victory statue is another tribute to Sir Arthur's legacy.For more info or to donate, go to blindveterans.org.uk

title: brexit news irish border ireland france emmanuel macron theresa may
story: Brexiteer MP pledges to IGNORE the 'tidy minds of eurocrats'                 Labour MP grilled for 'patronising' Brexit response in heated debateThe lifeline from the president's Elysee Palace in Paris yesterday followed fears among officials that today's gathering of EU leaders in Brussels is unlikely to break the deadlock.President Macron is seen as a key figure in the negotiations whose outspoken criticism of Britain's Brexit vote led to the Prime Minister's proposals being rebuffed at an earlier summit in Salzburg last month.But his officials yesterday indicated that fresh proposals for a temporary backstop contingency plan as an insurance policy designed to keep no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic could be put on the table.Their compromise included a guarantee the so-called backstop would be temporary but without too precise an end date, the Elysee Palace source said.A tense meeting of Mrs May's Cabinet spent two and a half hours discussing the stalled Brexit negotiations yesterday ahead of her trip to Brussels.She insisted that a deal was possible, telling her ministers: I am convinced that if we as a government stand together and stand firm we can achieve this.Brexit news: France appears to be backing down over the border backstop (Image: )Ministers were said to have stayed united following concerns some could quit if the Prime Minister went too far in compromising with Brussels.The concerns were intensified after eight pro-Brexit ministers including Michael Gove, Dominic Raab and Jeremy Hunt met over pizzas in Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom's office the evening before Cabinet to discuss the Government's position in the negotiations.But insiders said there were no resignation threats at the Cabinet meeting yesterday.Instead, ministers spent much of the discussions focused on how to come up with a mechanism to ensure any backstop cannot become permanent, trapping the UK in the EU customs union indefinitely.Attorney General Geoffrey Cox was said to have delivered a masterful contribution about how the EU's latest proposal for a backstop for a backstop was unacceptable.Following the meeting, the Prime Minister's spokesman said: She said we have made progress on a huge number of issues in the negotiations but there remained sticking points in two key areas.The PM said it is not possible for her or any UK prime minister to sign up to an agreement that would lead a customs border down the Irish Sea.Brexit news: Emmanuel Macron may be backing down over the Irish border (Image: )She said we also need to ensure that we do not have a situation where the UK will be kept indefinitely in the backstop against our will.Dominic Raab, the Brexit Secretary, joined a number of ministers in thanking the UK's negotating teams for their hard work. He said good progress had been made on the withdrawal agreement and on the future framework.Cabinet strongly supported the Prime Minister over the importance of maintaining the integrity of the union.Cabinet also agreed that we must be able to ensure that we cannot be kept in the backstop arrangement indefinitely.The PM said there will no doubt be challenging moments ahead, that is in the nature of negotiations.She said she is committed to ensuring a Brexit that delivers on the referendum results, safeguards jobs and security and which preserves our union.Before the Cabinet meeting, two ministers present at the pizza summit played down suggestions of rebellion against the Prime Minister.International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt told Sky News: No-one is planning on resigning.We are all doing our jobs and we are trying to get the best deal for this country, and that's it.Brexit news: The Irish border has been the biggest obstacle facing the UK (Image: )We are approaching the end of negotiations. This is going to be a difficult time, but the whole Cabinet is digging in to get the best deal for this country.And Mrs Leadsom said: The Prime Minister is doing a very, very complicated job and I'm fully supporting her in getting that done.EU Council President Donald Tusk attempted to increase the pressure on Mrs May to come forward with new concrete proposals at the summit and claimed there were no grounds for optimism about the chances of a deal.As I see it, the only source of hope for a deal for now is the goodwill and determination on both sides, Mr Tusk told a Brussels press conference.However, for a breakthrough to take place, besides goodwill we need new facts.Tomorrow I am going to ask Prime Minister May whether she has concrete proposals on how to break the impasse. Only such proposals can determine if a breakthrough is possible.EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier yesterday said that more time was needed to find an agreement to deliver an orderly UK withdrawal and keep the Irish border open.We will take this time, calmly and seriously, to find this global agreement in the next weeks, he said.Germany's Europe minister, Michael Roth, said Berlin's message to Mrs May was: Take responsibility and be constructive.

title: brexit news Michael Fabricant eu summit no deal brexit
story: Brexiteer Michael Fabricant revealed the reasons behind the EU's strategy (Image: REUTERS IMAGES)The Tory backbencher said the UK&rsquos departure has left the bloc fighting for &ldquosheer survival with the very future of the European project at stake.He said granting Britain any special exceptions could &ldquoopen Pandora&rsquos Box and embolden disgruntled member states like Hungary and Poland to make similar demands.And he predicted Brussels&rsquo relentless pursuit of an &ldquoever closer union could ultimately trump the economic damage inflicted on member states by a no-deal Brexit.The stark warning from the Tory backbencher comes as Theresa May is in the Belgian capital for crunch talks with EU leaders in what is likely to be one of the final chances for the UK to secure an exit deal.                BREXIT LIVE: May's plea FALLS FLAT as EU REFUSES to budge                Ex-Brexit secretary pledges to STAND UP for Brexit and CHUCK ChequersBut despite signs of progress during negotiations last week, the prospect of a deal tonight now looks highly unlikely after it emerged there are still major disagreements over the Irish border and customs union.Writing in the Daily , Mr Fabricant said he understood the reasons behind the bloc&rsquos refusal to compromise on its key institutions.But he questioned whether leaders of the EU27 are prepared to blindly pursue the EU grand plan at any cost.He said: &ldquoOne thing is clear: if the EU lets us have our own way on Brexit, the very future of the European dream (or nightmare) could be doomed.&ldquoBut EU leaders also need to ask themselves this: are their lofty ideals really worth the price that will be paid in European jobs if Britain were to leave without any deal?Mr Fabricant said allowing the UK concessions could trigger the collapse of the EU (Image:  IMAGES)                Farage outlines EXACTLY what May needs to do to secure a Brexit deal                Brexit news: May TOO WEAK to deliver deal, warns Lithuanian presidentThe MP for Lichfield has previously described himself as an &ldquoardent Brexiteer and expressed support for Mrs May&rsquos Brexit blueprint.He said the soft Brexit proposals set out in the so-called Chequers deal are by no means perfect but are the only way to both restore sovereignty to the UK and boost its economy.But he acknowledged Chequers was always going to be an extremely tough sell.He said: &ldquoFor this grand European project to succeed, member states must continue to integrate their laws, political systems and arguably most importantly of all, their economies.&ldquoAfter decades of integration moving almost entirely in one direction, a compromise on something as fundamental as the Single Market or the Customs Union could set in motion a series of events which unravels the entire bloc.The EU27 will need to decide whether they are willing to risk job losses and economic damage (Image:  IMAGES)Mr Fabricant said the EU is already attempting to quell protests from some member states which have demanded major changes to the way the union operates.Countries including Poland and Hungary have opposed Brussels&rsquo plans for a bloc-wide migration policy while Italy is locked in a battle over its proposed budget.Mr Fabricant said while each member state has its own grievances, &ldquothe EU&rsquos approach and its rationale remains the same: to preserve uniformity across the bloc.He said: &ldquoWith the whole of Europe watching, our Brexit negotiations are likely to serve as a litmus test for how the EU deals with internal dissent for many years to come.&ldquoShould Brussels come out on top in its standoff with the UK, as it has done with so many other EU member states in the past when they don&rsquot vote the &ldquoright way in referendums, the message will be clear: Resistance is futile!&ldquoHowever, if the EU capitulates and makes a special exception for the UK, it could well open Pandora&rsquos Box, and lead to an escalation of dissent within the EU, with all and sundry demanding their own special deals.&ldquoWithin this context, it becomes clear that the EU is not acting out of spite or pettiness &ndash to them it is a matter of sheer survival.

title: Brexit news The Who Roger Daltrey UK EU withdrawal British music Bob Geldof latest
story: The Who frontman mocked colleagues like Bob Geldof and Ed Sheeran for joining forces to warn about the risks Brexit poses for the British music industry,Mr Daltrey trashed claims failing to secure a deal with the European Union would be reckless and threaten the cultural role the UK has carved for itself on the international stage.Speaking to the Today programme, he said: It&rsquos nothing that can&rsquot be solved. I mean, we used to work in Europe before Europe was even thought about, or the EU was even thought about.We had the golden period of the 60s and the 70s. I&rsquom not against Europe at all. It&rsquos Brussels &ndash&nbspthere are far too many people on far too many gravy trains soaking us dry.                Sting and Ed Sheeran JOIN Bob Geldof's latest anti-Brexit attack                Farage RIDICULES Bob Geldof's latest 'hysterical' ATTACK on BrexitThe Who founder lamented the democratic deficit of the EU, complaining about the lack of direct interaction between EU voters and the institutions.He continued: I&rsquove been very much in favour of Europe, I was very much in favour of the economic community but I was always, and have always been, against the construct of Brussels. I think it&rsquos a disaster.The construct of Brussels and the democratic deficit of it.&nbspThere's&nbspno direct link between the voter, and to get through to those people that run our lives, and there&rsquos far too many people on far too many gravy trains soaking us dry.Asked about possible complications for British artists to organising tours in Europe, Mr Daltrey appeared unphased.Brexit news: Daltrey rejected claims leaving the EU is bad for British music (Image: )He added: We did it in those days, it might be a bit more paperwork on this side of the Channel. I&rsquom sure they can make it hard if they want to but these things work both ways.Jarvis Cocker, Brian Eno, Damon Albarn, Johnny Marr, former The Smiths guitarist, and Pink Floyd's drummer Nick Mason have also joined forces in the anti-Brexit campaign.Launching his campaign in early October, Mr Geldof said: It's two-fold. One is the income it generates for this country, &pound94bn, contrast that to the NHS spend, of &pound115bn, almost the same.This will be critically damaged. The second reason is cultural - the voice of Britain, the genuine, global British voice is music, it has been since the Beatles.No one knows quite why this tiny island produces such vast reservoirs of talent but we do know the entire planet dances, eats, sleeps, and plays hard to our noise.That is being endangered by a recklessness which is existential and historically self-damaging.

title: Brexit news Henkel Donald Tusk UK EU withdrawal new deal border control latest
story: The German politician urged the top Eurocrat to offer Britain a new arrangement putting an end to freedom of movement, suggesting the change in strategy could stop Brexit.Mr Henkel implored Donald Tusk to step over his own shadow to reach a satisfactory withdrawal agreement with the UK &ndash claiming the end of free travel between the European Union and the UK might convince Brexiteers to backtrack on plans to leave the bloc.Speaking to Sky News, the German MEP said: President Tusk talked about a Gordian knot and he is right. I appeal to Mr Tusk to behave like Alexander the Great. He should cut this Gordian knot, he should step over his own shadow and offer Britain now a different solution when it comes to freedom of movement.This is either good for a better deal under the assumption of Brexit but it would also be good in case Britain changes its mind. Even the Brexiteers could then say &lsquook, we got what we always wanted without the disadvantages of Brexit.                Italian diplomat demands Britons 'satisfy EU needs' in heated TV clashMr Henkel insisted Brussels should stop behaving unreasonably and arrogantly, providing Britain with an alternative arrangement which would justify a new vote on membership to the EU.He continued: The European Union is behaving unreasonably at times and I think, sometimes, very arrogantly. In this particular case, however, I don&rsquot see any real solution.My suggestion is the Commission stops linking trade always with freedom of movement, offers Britain a new deal and then give Britain the chance to rethink their decision.The German politician also rejected plans set forward by EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier to extend the Brexit transition period to December 2020.Brexit news: Mr Henkel implored Mr Tusk to offer Britain a new deal on freedom of movement (Image: SKY NEWS&bullEBS)Mr Henkel added: Extending that period by another year does not help. What would help is right now, if there was no deal by tomorrow and the next two weeks, the European Union offers Britain more time to negotiate.In other words, don&rsquot take this date of March 2019 too seriously. Give them a little bit more time to come up with a deal.Delay Article 50 because that is better than a no deal Brexit. No deal Brexit would be a total disaster for both, Britain and also the European Union.Mr Tusk revealed negotiations have become &ldquomore complicated than was previously predicted as both sides reach yet another impasse on the Irish border conundrum.The warning came in his invitation letter to European leaders, who will gather in the Belgian capital on Wednesday evening for crunch discussions about the United Kingdom&rsquos orce from the EU.Negotiations are currently &ldquopaused as both sides struggle to agree on the highly disputed Irish backstop, according to a senior EU diplomat.

title: Brexit news Theresa May SNP Nicola Sturgeon fisheries UK EU Scotland withdrawal latest
story: The Prime Minister swiftly rejected Mr Blackford's demands, pointing out her proposed Brexit deal would protect the interests of all citizens across the country.Mrs May suggested the SNP join the Government into putting an end to the rule of the European Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) if they are interested in safeguarding the livelihoods of Scottish workers.Exchanging barbs with the SNP MP during a heated PMQs session, the Prime Minister said: As I have explained to this chamber on a number of occasions and will continue to do, the proposal we have put forward is one that delivers on the referendum but also ensures we protect jobs and livelihoods across the United Kingdom.But if the Right Honourable Gentleman is interested in ensuring the interests of everybody in Scotland are taken into account, he should join with us in recognising the importance of leaving the Common Fisheries Policy.                French fishermen could CLASH with British boats after Brexit                British fishing FIGHTS BACK with defiant message for &lsquosinking&rsquo EUThe Scottish National Party has made no attempt to disguise their dissent with Brexit, recently suggesting the party could support calls for a second referendum if connected to a new vote on Scottish independence.&nbspQuestioning Mrs May, Mr Blackford said: Prime Minister, go to Brussels and act in the interest of all citizens across in the UK and negotiate to keep us in the single market and customs union. That will command a majority in the House of Commons.Does the Prime Minister not understand that staying in the single market and the customs union is the only deal that will get through this House?Despite voicing opposition to the CFP and it granting permission to EU vessels to catch fish in British waters, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has remained an outspoken critic of Brexit &ndash going as far as suggesting Scotland be allowed to stay in the single market in 2017.Brexit news: Theresa May called on the SNP to join the Government to get Scotland out of the CFP (Image: PARLIAMENT TV)Research from Kent&rsquos School of Anthropology and Conservation suggested the CFP harms fishing communities' livelihoods and put their survival at risk, while in turn making the rich richer.Professor Douglas MacMillan, one of the researchers taking part in the study, said the CFP focuses too much on fish stock conservation and has no meaningful policy regulations to ensure that quotas for over-fished stock such as tuna are equally shared amongst fishermen.He said: &ldquoThis allows inidual nations to implement their own policies, which more often than not are captured by local elites to enhance their wealth and power through, for example, capturing all the quota.&ldquoFurthermore, additional conservation measures such as no-fishing zones are crude and tend to curtail all fishing activity over large segments of coastal waters, regardless of whether the fishing undertaken there is sustainable or not.British fishermen believe UK waters are overfished by other EU countries and the CFPmeans they are also restricted as to how much they can fish. The strict EU regulations mean that some British fishermen are forced to throw fish back into the sea.

title: Brexit news UK latest Northern Irish border Julian Lewis PMQs Theresa May
story: Rows over the Irish border have deadlocked Brexit negotiations in Brussels for weeks.Speaking during this afternoon&rsquos session of Prime Minister&rsquos Question Time, Brexiteer MP stood up to ask Theresa May who would actually enforce a hard border in Ireland.Mr Lewis said: &ldquoNext time shroud waving EU negotiators claim that a hard border is necessary on the island of Ireland, will she kindly ask them who would actually construct it?&ldquoThe Irish certainly won&rsquot, the British certainly won&rsquot, so unless the EU army plans to march in and build it, it surely can never happen!                PMQs LIVE: Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn go head-to-head after inte...                'Chequers NOT DEAD' Theresa May shocks Brexiteers with Brexit outburstPrime Minister Theresa May responded: &ldquoCan I say to my honourable friend that we are all working to ensure that there will be no hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.&ldquoit is the clear commitment of the United Kingdom government, as agreed by the European Union when we signed the December joint report.This afternoon, Irish leader Leo Varadkar has demanded Theresa May honour her word and make good on her previous commitment to a &lsquobackstop&rsquo safety net for the Irish border after Brexit.Irish leader Leo Varadkar said he expected a country with as proud a history as Britain not to renege on terms agreed in December 2017designed to keep the frontier open if the UK leaves without a deal.Brexit news: Julian Lewis made the comments during Prime Minister's Question Time (Image: Parliament TV)Both Britain and the European Union agreed to ensure Brexit would not lead to a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.But the deal, which was signed off in March, also includes a controversial clause which stipulates &ldquofull alignment between Northern Ireland and the EU on trade if the UK fails to secure a trade deal.If implemented, it would effectively see Great Britain leave the customs union while Northern Ireland is forced to stay in - an outcome Mrs May&rsquos unionist allies in Belfast have warned is completely unacceptable.But Ireland has now accused the British Government of &ldquobacksliding on its commitments.                Michael Gove promises the Royal NAVY will DEFEND fishing watersAddressing the Irish parliament today, Mr Varadkar said: All we are asking is that the United Kingdom honour the commitments it has already made in black and white in the year gone by and I'm sure a country like the United Kingdom, with its proud history, would want to do no less.He said he still believes a positive outcome is possible in the Brexit talks but warned a breakthrough is needed quickly.He said: I am disappointed and concerned, despite these efforts, it has not been possible to make the decisive progress we so urgently need. The gaps between the positions are significant and time is running out.Theresa May will travel to Brussels tomorrow to attend a crunch summit with EU leaders in what will be one of the final chances to secure a orce deal with the bloc.A solution to avoid customs checks and border infrastructure along the politically sensitive frontier between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is the last major hurdle to overcome but there are still &ldquosignificant gaps left to bridge, Mr Varadkar said.EU officials today warned Mrs May she must demonstrate progress has been made towards a consensus or an emergency summit planned for November would be cancelled.Brussels&rsquo backstop proposals would see Northern Ireland remain in the customs union and much of the single market while a trade deal which includes a border solution is drawn up.But the British Government has dismissed this as unacceptable with Mrs May likening the plan to &ldquocarving off part of the country.

story: Retired British Army officer Major General Tim Cross criticised what he called the &ldquoselfie generation adding that Remembrance Day was about recognising sacrifice on a large scale was made in the past.Mr Cross reacted after the town&rsquos mayor in Saltash, Cornwall, cancelled a Remembrance Day parade over health and safety concerns.Speaking on talkRADIO, Mr Cross said: &ldquoWe&rsquore living in what I call the iPad, iPod, iPhone, selfie generation, where &lsquoit&rsquos all about me&rsquo.&ldquoWhat Remembrance Sunday is about us inidually collectively as a nation recognising that sacrifice on a large scale was made by young men and women, mostly men in the first world war but a lot of young women too. title: benefits blunder 70000 people owed money
story: Furious MPs have ripped into Ministers after it emerged Brits claiming Employment and Support Allowancehad been underpaid by a total of up to £ million since .Some may also have missed out on free prescriptions and seen their kids go without free school meals.A withering report from the National Audit Office revealed a whopping £ million in compensation will now be paid out to the claimants – who include severely disabled Brits.But the Government will not pay all of this back until April .And it is refusing to pay an extra £ million in compensation from before  – due to “legal restrictions”.Taxpayers will also have to pick up a £ million bill as the DWP is forced to splash out to redeploy  staff and hire more to review hundreds of thousands of ESA cases.Labour’s Meg Hillier, chair of cross-party Public Accounts Committee said the scale of the chaos revealed by the National Audit Office defied belief.She told The Sun: “Some of the poorest people in the UK have been screwed by the Government. I’m very angry about this and will be demanding an explanation.”The DWP was supposed to assess claimants for ESA on the basis of both their National Insurance contributions and any income.TENS of thousands of ill or disabled people were underpaid benefits by an average of around £,, a watchdog has found.But “in practice it did not always do this” and many missed out on income related payments, the NAO said.Despite the Government being aware of the issue as long ago as  it only recognised it had a “legal responsibility” to act in July .On average ESA claimants are owed £, but some on a severe disability premium could be owed £, each.A “small number” could be owed around £,.ESA is designed to help people unable to work because of an illness or disability.NAO chief Amyas Morse said: “The facts of this case are that tens of thousands of people, most of whom have severely limiting disabilities and illnesses, have been underpaid by thousands of pounds each, while the Department for several years failed to get a grip on the problem.”Last night the DWP revealed it had so far reviewed , cases and found mistakes in , of them. A spokesman insisted compensation should be paid within  weeks of initial contact with a claimant.She said: “We’re well underway with our plan to identy and repay people affected by this issue, and payments have already started.“We’re committed to ensuring people get what they are entitled to receive as quickly as possible. Everyone who could be affected will be contacted directly by the department.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. Once the gun is fired, half the Cabinet and plenty of hopefuls will join in.Everyone deserves blame, including Brexiteers who assumed the game was over after their victorious out vote and abandoned the field. Remainers are at fault for refusing to accept the will of the people — and the shortcomings of their beloved EU.But it is Downing Street, and Theresa May personally, who must take responsibility. Mrs May has dreamed of being Prime Minister since she was a child.It’s a tough job. It means leading from the front, making swt decisions and rallying the country with confidence and authority in dficult times.Instead, Mrs May’s team talk like defeatists about parliamentary “arithmetic”. How can she push through a dficult Brexit against ferocious opposition without a commanding Commons majority  But who was responsible for that parliamentary arithmetic It was Theresa May alone who decided to call an unforced election and it was she who single-handedly blew it. Her only task was to deliver the referendum mandate handed to her by .million voters. She blew that, too.People knew the risks. They did not vote for us to stay half-in, half-out or to see our sovereignty handed over to foreign powers. To govern is to decide. Mrs May made a career out of being the strong and silent type.Many of her MPs worry she is actually weak, vacillating and inarticulate.We are becoming accustomed to ruthless “wet jobs” by authoritarian tyrannies such as Russia, North Korea and the People’s Republic of China, many of them “friends” of Jeremy Corbyn.But Saudi Arabia has always revelled in public and private bloodshed. When it comes to terrorism, all roads lead back to Riyadh.A respectable MP, who does not joke about such matters, tells me the Saudi Embassy in London once had a torture chamber in the basement.I wonderit still does Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories need to stand behind pm
story: On Wednesday, she flies to Brussels for the European Council summit.With mounting Cabinet unease over the prospect of a Customs Union fudge, it is, as one Government source puts it, “squeaky bum time”.Four potential ministerial resignations loom over fears Britain could be tied to a permanent Customs Union. And Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson and Scottish Secretary David Mundell could resignNorthern Ireland is granted special status in any EU deal.The DUP and Remain Tory MPs also threaten Mrs May’s survival.Brexit chief Dominic Raab flew to Brussels yesterday for last-ditch talks. We must secure a time-limit agreement for the temporary Customs Union — remaining in it by the next election would stop us from striking any meaningful trade deals outside the EU.Meanwhile, Tories threatening mutiny should consider what will happenthey try to oust the PM. It will spark a bloody leadership battle that will strengthen Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour.It could also lead to a General Election in which the Tories will likely be punished by an unforgiving public, irritated at being dragged to the polls yet again.This week the PM must present her solution to the Irish border and reiterate her commitment for a No Deal Brexit, in which our £billion cheque would be taken off the table.And the Tory party needs to stand firmly behind her — for now. Too much is at stakethey implode.BRITAIN has the steepest air tax in Europe.So it is right that politicians are calling on Philip Hammond to slash air passenger duty in the budget. Cutting it will make holidays cheaper for families who have been hit by pricier trips because of the weaker Pound.On long haul flights, there is a £ tax on an economy ticket. This is a huge leap from  when it was just £.There is no environmental justication, it is simply used to fill the Treasury’s coffers. Slashing it will also boost businesses hoping to sell products outside of the EU.It will show Brexit Britain is an outward-looking, global nation.We hope you’re listening, Mr Hammond.JEREMY Kyle was inspired to see a doctor after reading a Sun article about testicular cancer.Before that, the TV favourite had been hesitant to seek advice after he found a lump.One in  blokes will have testicular cancer in their letime. title: this is your brexit boudicca moment theresa its time to say on your way barnier like up yours delors
story: I could see where he was going with this. After all, as we remember from school, this ancient British queen rose up against the Roman Empire, winning battles, slaughtering enemies and forcing the Romans to contemplate leaving Britain all together.“But, hang on,” I replied. “Wasn’t Boudicca eventually defeated ”Whatever the details, my friend was right. It is time for Theresa May to call on her deepest reserves of defiance and stand up to the European Union.Brussels has rejected her Brexit proposals, insulted us at the recent Salzburg summit and wants to dismember the United Kingdom by effectively annexing Northern Ireland for itself.Theresa May’s respect towards the EU has been met consistently with contempt for Britain. She has wished Brussels every success, while they wish us nothing but failure and decline. She has suggested solutions while they point out problems. And she has taken her Government to the brink by proposing a future relationship that is hated by many of her own MPs and supporters.It is time, now, to stop.Her Chequers plan already goes too far. It would tie us to European laws, over which we would have no say, and force us to accept the rulings of the European Court of Justice.It would prevent us from taking our own decisions and making our economy more competitive. And it almost certainly stops us from striking our own trade deals.Worse still,the Government persists with Chequers, we will end up with something even worse: Chequers Minus, which could mean making annual payments to Brussels, complying with more EU laws and accepting liberal immigration rules that amount to continued free movement.The longer we pretend Chequers can survive, the worse the outcome will be. As we negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, Britain should be seeking watertight assurances about our future relationship. Without them, we will sign away a £billion orce payment without any confidence we will get a fair deal for the future.But the crisis the Prime Minister described to Parliament yesterday, and which the Cabinet will discuss today, is not about Chequers, but the so-called “backstop” — what should happen to Northern Irelandthere is no eventual agreement on the future relationship.The EU’s proposition is an outrage. If there is no deal on the future relationship, they expect Northern Ireland to remain inside the Customs Union and, in effect, the single market.That would mean, in trying to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, we would create a hard border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain. That’s right, a border within our own country to avoid having one with another.The backstop would mean politicians in the Republic have a say over laws in Northern Ireland, while politicians in Belfast and London would have none. And it effectively breaches the Good Friday Agreement, which demands that Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom is respected unless a majority of Northern Irish people vote for the reunication of Ireland.The one concession the EU seems willing to make is that the whole of the United Kingdom can remain inside the Customs Union, not just Northern Ireland.But it insists there can be no time limit, and no right for the UK to unilaterally withdraw from the backstop.In other words, we would be trapped inside the Customs Union — following laws over which we have no say, letting Brussels grant trading access to our market for other countries and leaving us unable to agree trade deals of our own — for ever.This, of course, has always been the EU’s game. They have cynically used the Northern Irish peace process to try to tie the whole of the United Kingdom to the EU’s rules and regulations. And in their naivety, our negotiators have walked straight into the trap.The PM needs to tell the EU to get stuffed. And she must go back to the drawing board. She must replace Chequers with an ambitious, Canada Plus, free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. She must insist that the Northern Irish solution lies with technology and policy that avoid checks at the border. And she must tear up the backstop.One alternative, still a compromise for Brexiteers like me, is to agree that the UK will remain inside the Customs Union for a period of up to five years while the appropriate systems are put into place.Critics will say the EU will never agree. Butthey cannot accept a trade deal consistent with their principles and which respects the integrity of their single market, we know they seek only a damaging deal for Britain, or no deal at all.Others will say the Government could not get this kind of plan through the Commons. But it stands a better chance than Chequers Minus.This was, in fact, the plan Theresa May first set out at Lancaster House in January .There, she warned against a Chequers-style deal, saying: “We do not seek to hold on to bits of membership as we leave” and “we will not have truly leftwe are not in control of our own laws”.And she warned against what the backstop demands. She insisted on creating “no new barriers to living and doing business within our own Union”, and warned against “an unlimited transitional status”, which she called a “kind of permanent political purgatory”.Instead, she sought “a comprehensive free trade agreement” and the freedom for “Britain to negotiate its own trade agreements” with other countries.In other words, she described the Canada Plus agreement that is prepared and drafted but gathering dust inside the Brexit Department.Many years ago, The Sun advised us to say “up yours, Delors” to a meddling European Commissioner. Today, the PM needs to find her inner Boudicca and say: “On your way, Barnier.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding soap opera
story: Too much décolletage or, God forbid, a side split and one risks what has now become known in common parlance as “doing a Raquel Welch”, who didn’t so much upstage the bride at her son’s ­wedding as eclipse her completely.And so, paralysed by the uncertainty of it all, the majority of “immediate family” wedding snaps feature the loving couple, a couple of blokes chilling in their usual suits, and two middle-aged women looking deeply uncomfortable in unforgiving taffeta and a hat that resembles an upturned lamp shade.Or, in Sarah Ferguson’s case, a titfer reminiscent of a stewardess for a s Eastern Bloc airline. Then, to keep up appearances for the family photo, Sarah had to hover nervously behind the gimlet-eyed former father-in-law who has ignored her for the past  years.But worst of all, she had to stand by and watch Prince Harry and his glossy new we sweep in and steal bride Eugenie’s thunder with news of their impending baby.A child, I might add, with the added sting of bumping the bride and her sister Beatrice even further down the line of succession.Far from feeling like a “royal wedding”, it bore all the hallmarks of a Hello! or OK!-funded celebrity shindig, or worse, an excerpt from US prime-time soap opera The Royals, starring Elizabeth Hurley.Take the, er, crowds gathered outside Windsor’s St George’s Chapel.“Who are you hoping to catch a glimpse of ” asked a TV reporter.“George Clooney,” came the cheerful reply.Someone  was hoping for David Beckham. They got neither.Both couples claimed other commitments but, given that they all took centre stage at Harry and Meghan’s nuptials and the Beckhams also made the cut for William and Kate’s big day, perhaps they felt this wasn’t A-list enough Instead, we had to make do with, among others, models Naomi Campbell, Cara ­Delevingne and Kate Moss, X Factor judges Robbie Williams and Ayda Field, and actresses Demi Moore and Liv Tyler.Some of whom uploaded gushing videos from the event and Instagram photos of their outfits with hashtag plugs for ­ious clothing brands.At a “royal” wedding  The notoriously traditional Queen Mother must be turning in her grave.There will be the modernisers within the palace walls who regard this as “progress” for a monarchy that, as they see it, must appeal to a younger generationit is to survive.But to my mind, it’s the complete opposite.The pomp, ceremony, tradition, duty and, most importantly, ­mystique of the royals is what sustains them.This wedding — between a “Princess” who performs no royal duties and her Jack of tequila trade — has shone a ­spotlight on the blindingly obvious threat that, once the dutul Queen and Prince Philip are no longer with us, the ­“modern” monarchy will continue to make ever decreasing circles until the taxpayer finally decides, “Hang on — they’re just like us” and the game will be up.With this #royalwedding where even the bride’s mother, left, Instagrammed a designer plug “for my amazing dress” that threat has just come one step closer.RITA ORA is promoting her new album Phoenix. “It’s my first global release of an album.I’m really excited to express my music to the world,” she says.But why the seemingly ­regular need to, er, express her breasts at the same time After all, Ed Sheeran has never posed in just his kecks and he’s sold  squillion records.ANGRY passengers on a flight from London Heathrow to Istanbul intervened to stop Home Office officials from deporting Somalian Yaqub Ahmed.“I know he’s scared,” protested one, before leading a chant of: “Take him off the plane, take him off the plane.”Though probably not as scared as the -year-old girl who was gang-raped in London by Ahmed and two of his equally unsavoury friends – the crime for which he was being deported before these witless do-gooders stepped in.Pitully, the officials capitulated and Ahmed is still in this country awaiting our next move.Meanwhile, as some of the passengers virtue-signalled their liberal credentials by posting footage of the showdown, perhaps they could now be identied and charged with obstructing the course of justice Or, at the very least, be asked to welcome the delightful Mr Ahmed into their own homes until such time as his removal can be rearranged Let’s seetheir liberalism extends to putting their own teenage daughters at risk.PIZZAS and pies must shrink to tackle obesity, claim new official guidelines from Public Health England.Sigh. Amazing, isn’t it, how millions of people manage to stay slim by eating healthily and doing moderate exercise while advocating the same mindset to their children Radical, I know, buta pizza is large, how about sharing it Or perhaps not buying it at all Or is a slice of personal responsibility too hard to swallow CHANNING Tatum and Jessie J are dating.We know this because they’ve been spotted ­laughing together at a mini-golf course.Ah yes, those heady, early months of dating when you’re presenting the best side of yourself and pretending you just love doing kooky stuff like ­hitting a ball into the clown’s mouth or paddling in pointless circles around the local ­boating lake.Then the eager-to-please phase passes and, before you know it, you’re watching ­separate TV shows in dferent parts of the house. And what a blessed relief it is too.QUESTION Time is holding a series of auditions for potential David Dimbleby replacements such as Kirsty Wark, Emily Maitlis, Nick Robinson and Julie Etchingham.They are each chairing a  of politicians and journalists in front of a live audience – the only dference being the programmes won’t be broadcast.Meaning that every last one will be far better than the real thing where, with a few notable exceptions, participants now sanitise their every utterance for fear of being publicly mauled by the kangaroo court of social media.GWYNETH  Paltrow and her new husband Brad Falchuk now refer to them- selves as “The Faltrows”. title: brexit deal latest there may britain could stay tied to eu another year
story: Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels last night, the PM told them she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest,  months longer than No’s current transition plan.And that would include continuing free movement of all migrants, as well as the UK having to fork out another £bn into EU coffers in fees, while having no say in any Brussels decision making.The PMs high stakes play runs the risk of infuriating hardline Brexiteers who have long opposed keeping any ties to the EU beyond Brexit day on March , let alone for almost three more years.An EU official told reporters after Mrs Mays speech: She said the UK would be ready to consider the extension of the transition period.European Parliament President Antonio Tajani, who was also invited to listen to the PM’s  minute address, confirmed her signicant move.MEPs’ boss Mr Tajani said of the summit discussion: “Both sides mentioned the idea of an extension of the transition period as one possibility which is on the table and would have to be looked into.Downing Street had earlier insisted a transition extension was “not something we are calling for”.But Mrs May herself refused a point blank chance to rule it out, ducking a direct question from ITV News on her arrival in Brussels.Mrs May left the dinner after her half-hour speech, as the other  leaders enjoyed a meal of turbot cooked in beer.But Tory MPs lined up to slap down her suggestions just minutes later.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries said thatshe was suggesting a transition extension, she should step aside - and slammed the billions that could now be spent paying more to the EU.Its time to stand aside and let someone who can negotiate get on with it and deliver. I fully support DD [David Davies] as interim leader, she added.Andrea Jenkyns agreed, telling ITVs Peston: It’s ludicrous that it’s two years on and we haven’t got a deal. Extending [the transition] just kicks it into the long grass.And John Redwood said her plans would be unacceptable, saying: I dont think MPs would vote for it.Nigel Farage added: This is another betrayal of Brexit... I dont think she can survive this.He speculated it could mean British taxpayers having to pay an extra £BILLION to the EU.But Tory Deputy Chairman James Cleverly played down the suggestion of extending the transition period - pointing out that it was only a proposal from the EU.He refused to rule it out, but said Michel Barnier put forward a proposal which our Prime Minister and negotiating team will think about.The PM also held separate meetings with Donald Tusk, Jean-Claude Juncker, Emmanuel Macron and Irish PM Leo Varadkar today.But despite the high level talks, EU leaders said tonight that despite intensive negotiations there had not been enough progress between negotiators to come to a deal.They said that a November summit was off the cards for now, but stood ready to hold a December one in the hope that a deal could be sealed there instead.No had already given up any hope of forging a orce deal at the summit before it even started.The Brexiteer called the EU “a gravy train soaking us dry”.It had been billed as the “moment of truth” for an agreement before last weekend’s big row.Mrs May also asked the leaders to show “courage” to help her break the impasse.And despite talks stalling over Ireland yet again when a deal brokered by bureaucrats collapsed on Sunday, she also insisted an agreement was possible and appealed for them to come up with “creative” ways to help her.Mrs May told the leaders: We have shown we can do dficult deals together constructively. I remain confident of a good outcome.The last stage will need courage, trust and leadership on both sides.After she delivered the pitch, Mrs May was then asked to leave the summit room so her fellow national could deliberate over her words with dinner.The PM ed to the UK Representative to the EU’s official residence in Brussels for dinner alone with her aides.Under Mr Barnier’s proposal to extend the transition period, Mrs May must inagree to keep the whole of the UK in an indefinite customs union as a backstop to keep the Irish border opentrade talks to deliver another solution fail.But Mrs May has already ruled that out, and Cabinet ministers have demanded a legally binding mechanism to ensure any backstop is only temporary.Ireland’s Taoiseach Leo Varadkar gave his backing to the extension as one way of breaking the Irish border deadlock, but only under Mr Barnier’s conditions.Mr Varadkar said: Any extension to the transition period couldnt be a substitute for the backstop.We would still need to have that, but perhaps it would allow people to have greater confidence that it would never need to be invoked.”Some EU leaders began to express open doubts that Mrs May will ever be able to strike a deal with them because of Tory party turmoil over Brexit.Lithuanian president Dalia Grybauskaitė: We do not know what they want, they do not know themselves what they really want - thats the problem.“If you have on the other side of the table a negotiator who has no strong mandate, its very dficult to negotiate.”Ms Grybauskaitė, dubbed her country’s own ‘Iron Lady’ because of her black belt in karate, added: “The Brits must decide finally want they want, and rally behind the Prime Minister and not split, not battling, to have a joint opinion and joint stance.”But other EU leaders were more optimistic, including France’s Emmanuel Macron who said the EU would “find deals” to secure an orderly Brexit.The French president last night emerged as a key figure of support for Mrs May to break the Ireland impasse, having lead the way in torpedoing her trade deal proposals at a summit in Salzburg last month.Mr Macron was one of four EU leaders that Mrs May held one-to-one meetings with in Brussels ahead of the summit’s start.Another pivotal player, Germany’s Angela Merkel, was also supportive, saying: “We want good relations with Britain.“We would have been happythe exit deal was ready. Instead, we are  percent there.But I will tackle the issues in good spirit and try everything to find an agreement.”It also emerged tonight that Mrs May has invited  chief executives to take part in a conference call on Friday to brief them on the status of Brexit negotiations.The invitations, which were sent out today, are part of efforts by Downing Street to build a closer relationship with business.And in a blow to the PM, French officials today published a paper stating that in a No Deal scenario, British visitors to France would in principle need a visa to enter the country, and would be considered illegal immigrantsthey failed to apply for one.The document also revealed that French ministers are planning to implement new border checks the day after Brexitthe two sides fail to agree a deal.Its the first time a major European country has publicly announced plans for how it would cope with a No Deal outcome.On a crucial day in the Brexit process:At the start of todays summit, some leaders expressed optimism about the chances of a deal - Dutch PM Mark Rutte said: Im cautiously optimistic that over the coming weeks Michel Barnier and the negotiating team in the UK will come to conclusions.Angela Merkel claimed a deal was  per cent done, adding: I’m approaching this with the spirit of always trying to do everything to find an agreement.But Lithuanias president Dalia Grybauskaite said the UK had yet to agree its own negotiating position.She said Britain needs to rally behind the Prime Minister all together and not split - to have a joint opinion and joint stance.And chief negotiator Michel Barnier added: We are not there yet. Brexit must be orderly for everyone and for all the issues, including on the island of Ireland.So we need time, we need much more time, and we will continue to work in the next weeks calmly and patiently.Belgiums Charles Michel said: We are concerned because we see it is dficult in the British Parliament to have the same views on the future of the relationship between the EU and UK.The EU meeting which started today was previously earmarked as the moment when leaders would sign off an a withdrawal agreement.But talks broke down over the weekend after the EU insisted on a border backstop which could carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Mrs May told a Cabinet meeting yesterday that she wont accept any deal which which breaks up the Union - or which keeps Britain tied to the EU customs union permanently.And speaking to MPs in the Commons today, the PM said: We continue to work for a good deal with the European Union - a deal that delivers on the Brexit vote but also a deal that protects jobs and livelihoods and crucially that protects the precious Union of the United Kingdom.We will not accept any proposals which would effectively break up the United Kingdom.She accused Jeremy Corbyn of preparing to betray voters by laying the ground for a second referendum on Brexit.Mrs May also rejected the Labour leaders claim that her Chequers proposals are dead after she failed to mention them by name in two recent speeches.Today Michael Gove suggested that a deal might not be signed until December - just three months before we officially quit the EU.He told a Commons committee: It might be the case - we’ve seen how European negotiations work - that progress is made at October council, progress is made at the November council, and it is even as late as the December council before a deal is done.Obviously, everyone wants the deal to be done earlier.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt claimed one of the biggest threats to Brexit is Tory MPs like Boris Johnson who refuse to back Mrs Mays approach.He told the Daily Mail: Boris is a backbencher so he is free to say exactly as he thinks.But what I would say to Boris is be careful because there is a real danger thatall of us Conservative MPs do not stand behind the Prime Minister at a moment like this, the danger is that Brexit will be derailed altogether.I am sure that this is last thing Boris wants.The pro-EU veterans made a direct appeal to politicians across the EU, asking them to back calls for a second referendum.They wrote a joint opinion piece which appeared today in a number of European newspapers.The trio said: Our domestic debate is far from over and, even at this late hour, many of us are continuing to make the case that the British public need to make the final decision once we are in possession of all the relevant facts.So we ask our European partners to be ready to give us the space and time,necessary, to make such a final decision.They accused Brexiteers of being cynical pessimists who want to get a flimsy exit deal that they would later tear up in order to impose deregulation and tax cuts.The ex-PM and two former deputies have been blasted by Brexit-backing MPs who say they are undermining Britains negotiating position.

title: brits set for 230 a year pension boost and more money in your pocket as inflation drops
story: Pensioners will see a boost of almost £ a week from next April, and hard-working families will start to feel an ease to the cost of living squeeze.Inflation fell to . per cent from . per cent last month, as food and drink cost less.It means hard-up Brits will have more money in their pockets as they gear up for Christmas shopping.Mike Hardie, head of inflation at the ONS, said: Food was the main downward pull on inflation as last years September price rises failed to reappear, while ferry prices dropped after their surprisingly high summer peak.However, it wasnt all one-way traffic with energy suppliers pushing up their prices.And yesterday wages were shown to be rising by the fastest pace in nearly a decade - which will mean a boost for those on the state pension.This months figures are used to set public sector pensions for next April.Thanks to the triple lock, Brits will see a boost depending on which is higher - inflation, earnings or . per cent.Earnings for May - July were . per cent - which means the state pension will get boosted by this much next April.It works out at a £. a week, or £ a year for those on the full new state pension who will next year get £..And those on the old basic state pension will get a boost from £. per week, to £..Steve Webb, Director of Policy at Royal London said today: Whilst the rates of working age benefits have been squeezed for many years, pensioners look set to enjoy another above-inflation increase.Those receiving the full rate of the new state pension should get an extra £. per week or just over £ per year”.But the benefits freeze is set to continue to squeeze  million families, experts also warned today.New analysis by the Resolution Foundation finds that the four-year freeze in working age benefits – including Child Benefit, Tax Credits, Universal Credit, JSA, ESA and Housing Benefit – will save £.bn annually by next year, with £.bn of those savings coming from next year’s freeze alone.That means that this years freeze alone will make families around £ a year worse off.The benefit freeze has been in place since April , and is about to go into its fourth year.Adam Corlett, Senior Economic Analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: “The Chancellor should prevent this hit to low-income families by cancelling the benefit freeze in his Budget later this month.”

title: 180000 brits are owed 5000 each after having their benefits underpaid by bungling officials
story: The Government will pay an average of £, to , disabled or ill claimants who were short-changed for years.The Department for Work and Pensions announced it faces a bill of nearly £billion for the blunder - three times as much as previously thought.It is the latest embarrassment for the department which is already under fire over the rollout of Universal Credit.Earlier this year, the DWP admitted it had underpaid thousands of claimants of Employment Support Allowance, which is intended for those too ill to work.Officials claimed , people were affected, with a total estimated cost of £million.But today they published an update which shows the numbers involved are much higher than previously thought.A total of , claimants are owed an average of £, each, with some due to be paid as much as £,.The overall bill to the taxpayer will be £million, most of which will be paid out over the next two years.Just  per cent of those affected have been paid the benefits they are owed.Civil servants are in the process of contacting the other , claimants and hope to be finished by next April.They are prioritising the most serious cases including those of people who are now terminally ill.Labour MP Neil Coyle blasted: Another criminal let-down of thousands of disabled people by a callous Government and a chaotic DWP.A spokesman for the DWP said: “Anyone affected by this historic error will receive all of the money they are entitled to.That is why we have created a dedicated team of over  staff to examine cases, and have paid back around £million so far.“We have worked with charities and other disability organisations to make sure that we are providing the right support to all affected claimants and are hiring and allocating more staff to do that.”

title: peoples votes brexit march route road closed
story: Heres what you need to know about the Peoples Vote March for the Future.The campaign group was launched at the Electric Ballroom in Camden, London on April ,  and is supported by Open Britain, the European Movement UK and Britain for Europe, amongst others.MPs Chuka Umunna, Anna Sobry, Layla Moran and Caroline Lucas as well as comedian Andy Parsons and Sir Patrick Stewart attended the launched of the campaign.The group is campaigning for a “final say on the Brexit deal”.There are more than , campaign supporters, , activists, and over a million followers on social media, with more joining every day, the group says.The Peoples Vote have organised a March for the Future on October  from Park Lane to Parliament Square.Explaining the reason for the march, the group said: Whether you voted leave or remain, nobody voted to make this country worse off, to harm jobs, to damage the NHS, to affect the future of millions of young people, or to make this country more ided.The more the shape of the final Brexit deal becomes clear, the more it is clear that it will do nothing to improve social justice, reduce inequality, increase our standard of living, or create a better future for future generations.We are demanding our democratic voice be heard on Brexit. Since the referendum in , new evidence has emerged on what we were once told would be “the easiest deal in history”.We now know the true cost of the orce bill, as well as the impact of Brexit on the NHS, workers’ rights and public services.This Government has failed on Brexit: there is no mandate for its car crash proposal or for a disastrous no-deal Brexit. We won’t let them get away with a bad deal - that’s why we will be there in Central London making the case for a People’s Vote.Previously, the People’s Vote organised a march for June ,  from Trafalgar Square to Parliament Square in central London.Attending the event were Gina Miller, Vince Cable, David Lammy and the actor Tony Robinson.The Mayor of London Sadiq Khan is set to speak at the rally in Parliament Square on October .He said: This Saturday, people from every corner of our country will travel to London to demand that the British people get the final say on Brexit.The Government is taking us towards either a bad Brexit deal or - worse still - no deal at all.Both these scenarios are a million miles from what was promised.People didn’t vote to make themselves poorer, to damage our NHS or to put jobs at risk.As Mayor of London, I am proud to welcome everyone joining the March for the Future and to add my voice to the calls for a public vote.Other speakers at the event include Dragons Den star Deborah Meaden, chef and TV host Delia Smith, Conservative MPs Anna Soubry and Sarah Wolaston, Green Party MP Caroline Lucas, Labour MP Chuka Umunna, and Lib Dem Leader Vince Cable.Meeting at midday, the Peoples Vote: March for the Future will start moving down Park Lane before turning left onto Piccadilly.From there, the march will turn right onto St James Place and continuing to Pall Mall, veering right past Trafalgar Square and onto Whitehall, past Downing Street and onto Parliament Square.Transport for London have yet to announce road closures for the march.

title: theresa may needs to say no
story: The proposal to keep us shackled to the EU for another year beyond the transition period is an outrageous non-starter.We have compromised far too much. This latest ruse is an insult she must repel.We would be in the farcical position of voting to Leave in June , yet still bound by Brussels rules until December  at the earliest.
