title: paul routledge labour must put
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Labour must put national interest first and help Theresa MayMirror columnist explains how his family served in the British Army - and he hasnt forgotten or never known the cataclysmic reality of Europe at war with itselfShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  OCT NewsopinionThe EU brought peace, trade, co-operation and freedom to travel where there had been enmity, rivalry and refugees "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailListen to me, just for a moment. I speak for many more of my generation than you might think. I was born in , when my country was fighting for its le against Nazi Germany and it was not clear that we would win. My father Harry was in the RAF in the Middle East. My Uncle Bob was a tail gunner in Lancasters over occupied Europe. My Uncle Jack, a Guardsman, had been invalided off the beaches at Dunkirk. Even my youthful Auntie Barbara was in the Auxiliary Territorial Service. This was total war – the Americans fighting and dying with us, for our freedom. At home it was all wartime austerity. Food and clothes were rationed. Travel was suspended. I ask you to remember because so many have either forgotten or never known the cataclysmic reality of Europe at war with itself. Remember the Blitz on London and Hull. Remember Sheffield, Coventry, Plymouth, Liverpool, Bath and York. Remember, Auschwitz, Treblinka, and the other death camps where millions of Jews were exterminated. Remember El Alamein, Tobruk, Normandy and all the battlegrounds where people gave their lives to free us from Hitler. Remember all these things and consider thoughtfully what must be done to ensure that these horrors never happen again.  The EU brought peace, trade, co-operation and freedom to travel where there had been enmity, rivalry and refugees.It is not perfect, made up of all the flaws of the people of an old, culturally and racially erse continent that historically has more often been at war than at peace. But it is nothing short of a miracle that they found the wisdom to get together in their common interest. I do not care what Theresa May brings back from Brussels, just so long as it keeps us good friends and partners with the rest of Europe. I want the peace that my father’s generation fought for to be preserved in perpetuity, for my children, and generations to come.

title: tories vote cover up impact
story: NewsTories vote to cover up impact of Universal Credit on peoples incomesThe Government defeated an attempt by Labour to force ministers to publish its analysis of the impact of the benefits shake-upShareCommentsByelizabeth arnoldMikey SmithPolitical reporterHarriet Line:,  OCT NewsTory benefits chief Esther McVey "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories today voted to cover up the impact of Universal Credit on peoples incomes. The Government defeated an attempt by Labour to force ministers to publish its analysis of the impact of the benefits shake-up. Labour described Universal Creditas a vehicle for cuts, but failed in their efforts to push ministers into releasing the documents, by  votes to , majority . Shadow work and pensions secretary Margaret Greenwood said UC had been beset with flaws in its design and delivery and was causing immense hardship.  Reacting to the vote, Ms Greenwood added in a statement: The Tories have voted to shamefully cover up the impact that Universal Credit is having on families and people who most need our support. But Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey insisted the Government had taken a mature approach to the roll-out and said it would continue. Opening an Opposition Day debate in the Commons, Ms Greenwood said: Universal Credit, the Governments flagship social security programme, has been beset with flaws in its design and delivery. Its causing immense hardship for many people wherever it is rolled out. It is hard to believe now, but UC was designed to lt people out of poverty and smooth the transition into work to ensure that it always pays. The reality is that UC is a vehicle for cuts.  Ms Greenwood said confusion about the transfer to UC was causing families real concern and that they deserve answers. Labours motion was the latest proposed use of an arcane parliamentary procedure to make the vote binding on the Government by issuing a humble address to the Queen asking her to require ministers to comply. It called for any briefing papers or analysis provided to the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions since January   on the impact of the roll-out of Universal Crediton recipients and household income and on benefit debts to be laid before Parliament. Ms McVey insisted the roll-out of Universal Credit would continue, but said she would ensure the Government get it right. We will make sure we get this benefit right. You know for why  Because the genuine concerns of the people on our backbenches want to get it right. She received backing from Tory Heidi Allen , who said she and fellow backbenchers believed the Secretary of State is listening to what needs to change with Universal Credit. She said that makes a mockery of the motion, and told MPs that there is not a single person, myself included, who will vote for the motion. Ms McVey told the Commons that disabled households would be pound better off through Universal Credit, as she defended the Governments approach. She said: Around one million disabled households will receive on average around pound more per month through Universal Credit, andwe were to follow the advice of the party opposite those one million disabled households would be pound worse off. Thats what the opposition are asking for.

title: tory council blows 1600 feast
story: NewsTory council blows £, on feast for councillors - after claiming theyre too skint to help disabled kidsEXCLUSIVE: North Yorkshire councillors pushed through a "fundamentally wrong" cut to free transport for children with special educational needs and disabilitiesShareCommentsByIan Johnson:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsChicken beast with lemon and herbs was served"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory-run council staged a lavish pound, taxpayer-funded feast for councillors - moments after claiming they were too skint to help disabled kids. North Yorkshire councillors overwhelmingly blocked a Labour motion to oppose the “fundamentally wrong” cut to free transport for children with special educational needs and disabilities . After the vote, councillors gorged on pavlova, roast beef, salmon and a DOZEN dferent cheeses. The council’s now reviewing its spending, which one Labour councillor has slammed. “In these times of austerity foisted upon us by this out of touch and uncaring government, it is imperative that every opportunity to ensure rate payers cash is ploughed back into the savaged front line services,” raged Cllr Tony Randerson. “Not being a cheese eater, I haven’t noticed all these dferent types of cheeses but I have to say I’m rather surprised at the cost of this meal. “I for one will not be partaking in this buffet any longer and will instruct the authority of my position in order that they do not waste food.” The meal, unearthed via the Freedom of Information Act, followed a February meeting where council tax was “reluctantly” hiked up.  Swingeing cuts in the region have so far resulted in libraries closing, buses axed and street lights switched off. At the meeting, North Yorkshire’s Deputy Leader, Conservative Gareth Dadd, warned: “The financial challenges will last well into the next decade.” However analysis of the costs revealed over pound was spent per councillor present on the meal - and some taxpayer’s found the cost hard to swallow. “So they can sit around eating cake and roast beef, but we have to walk home in the dark ” fumed North Yorkshire resident James Wainwright. “We are all in this together - even councillors - so why do they need a dozen cheeses  “Could they not just bring a packed lunch or go get a toastie down the pub ”  In total, pound,. was spent on feeding the  councillors - although almost a dozen didn’t even attend the meeting, The menu at Northallerton’s County Hall included:Seared Chicken Breast with Lemon  herbs Poached Salmon with Lemon  dill mayonnaise Roast British beef and roast ham Greek saladAnd in a further blow to Yorkshire residents, it emerged the council had previously included a smoked Lancashire on the cheese board. “It is asthe War of the Roses never happened!” added James. Over  councillors blocked a motion to tabled by Labour’s Eric Broadbent to stop transport being cut, despite a passionate plea to find savings where. “We believe that the changes proposed to transport for children with SEND are fundamentally wrong,” he said. “Whilst we understand that the Council need to make savings, we believe that this area provides a valuable service to those who are amongst the most vulnerable in society and it is the Council’s duty to exhaust all other areas before removing free transport for young people with SEND. “It is therefore proposed that the implementation of the cut is removed and the funding of the saving gap met from Reserves until such time as more acceptable proposals are developed.” To date, over poundm has had to be shaved from the council’s books. County Councillor Carl Les, North Yorkshire County Council’s Leader, stated: “Our full council meets four times a year and that is the only time that councillors are provided with lunch.

title: tory universal credit delay make
story: NewsTory Universal Credit delay will make no dference for million cash-strapped Britsmillion people will be on Universal Credit by the end of , a DWP chief has confirmed - regardless of a climbdown revealed this weekShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video -million-people-universal-credit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories Universal Credit delay will do nothing to help million cash-strapped Brits, the head of the DWP confirmed today. He revealed that vast number of people will be on the benefit by the end of  - regardless of a climbdown that emerged this week. It is a blow just hours after campaigners hailed plans to slow down the benefits rollout to only , people in the first year. Revealing the policy to MPs this week, Tory welfare chief Esther McVey claimed it would ensure the system is right. But today her most senior civil servant said that was not the whole story. Despite ministers easing off, it remains a fact that million people will be on Universal Credit by May  - and million by December , he said.  Whats more, those people are not due to receive any of the transitional payments Theresa May has hailed to stop people losing out. That is because both the transitional payments, and this weeks slowdown, relate to a process called managed migration - which is for existing benefit claimants. That process has nothing to do with new claimants joining the benefits system for the first time. Such new claimants will be put on UC in every area in the country from December , with no transition cash and no delay. And crucially, they will also include current benefit claimants whose circumstances change - eventhey are not new to the system at all.  Much of this we knew already. But the sheer number of people who wont be protected has now been confirmed by the governments top welfare official. Peter Schofield, Permanent Secretary at the Department for Work and Pensions , told MPs: We are currently at about .million on Universal Credit. That will then rise to around about million in May next year. By the end of  it will be around million. So thats my point. Managed migration to one side, the fact that we have rolled out Universal Credit to every JobCentre by the end of this year means all new claims are coming in.  And that builds volumes quite apart from managed migration. Frank Field, chairman of the Commons Work and Pensions Committee, said Mr Schofield seemed to be in total and utter denial about the problems of UC. Mr Field warned: It’s staggering that he can talk so calmly about millions more people claiming Universal Credit next year, while in the same breath admitting that around one in five claims are taking longer than five weeks to process.” Genevieve Edwards, Director of External Affairs at the MS Society, said she was really concerned vulnerable people will lose out - with some claimants being protected in the rollout and others not.  She added: It doesn’t make sense that a change of circumstance – like moving to an adapted house to manage your disability – could mean a benefit cut. “MS is an often painful and exhausting condition and thousands rely on ESA to live independently, so any loss of support could have a huge impact. The Government has to pause and fix Universal Credit so that disabled people continue to get the support they need.” Committee member Neil Coyle, a Labour MP, added: To move people without protections is an admission the government misled MPs and the public in claiming no one would be worse off under UC. Hundreds of thousands of disabled people and families will be made worse off unless Ministers listen now.  Appearing before the Commons Work and Pensions Committee, Mr Schofield admitted the influx of claimants would be a huge challenge. He said the non-managed migration process would only apply to new claimants, “unless they’ve had a change of circumstances that triggers a new claim, obviously, into Universal Credit. Labour MP Ruth George suggested the delay to managed migration would in fact leave the million people worse off - because otherwise some of them might have qualied for transition payments. Mr Schofield replied: Of course, the advantage of moving forward with managed migration is it locks in the transitional protection you’ve described. He added: You’re right - the poundbilion of managed migration transitional protection is there for people when we managed migrate. . The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Reports of a delay and climbdown this week came after campaigners warned UC was driving people to food banks, debt and prostitution. Managed migration was due to begin in earnest in July  and end in March . But it is now expected to end in December  - the ninth delay to UC - after Tory welfare chief Esther McVey revealed just , people would be migrated across in the first year. Separately, a document leaked to the BBC revealed plans to:Continue paying income support, ESA and jobseekers allowance for two weeks after someone makes a UC claim Reduce deductions when someone is paying back an advance loan from % to % of monthly benefit Give more help to the self-employed after warnings the policy will crush themSome of this, too, would only apply to people who migrate onto UC. BUT... A new, better climbdown could be on the way  Today Tory welfare chief Esther McVey signalled a further climbdown by saying people should keep more of their benefitsthey get a job. Currentlyyoure on Universal Credit, your payment tapers away by p for every extra pound you earn above pound a month. That taper rate has already been cut from p to p, and today Ms McVey hinted it could be reduced further. She told MPs: Under the legacy benefits there were punitive tax rates of over %. We have now brought that down to %. And... we should aim to get that taper rate down even further.

title: mum received haunting phone call
story: NewsMum received haunting phone call days after daughter vanished in  - fresh investigation examines mysteryThe mystery of Trudie Adams’ disappearance is the subject of ABCs latest true crime podcast Unravel which examines how the case has remained unsolved for  yearsShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsThe teenager vanished  years ago"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTrudie Adams vanished on her way home from a party in Newport, Sydney in  - and the mystery of her disappearance has still not been solved. The -year-old left the party in Sydneys northern beaches and hitched a lt, which was not uncommon as there was little public transport in the area. Just after midnight, her then boyfriend, Steven Norris, saw her get into a beige  van with no windows in the back. It was the last time any of Trudie Adams loved ones saw her. When she didnthome from the party, her family reported her missing.  Five days after her daughters disappearance, Trudies mum Connie received a haunting phone call from a mystery male. The voice said, Trudie is dead. You will find her about half way up Mona Vale Road. It was an accident. An identical phone call was made to Mona Vale police. Police searched the area but Trudie was never found. Despite four investigations and a coroner stating that the teen probably died of misadventure followed by a cover up, authorities are still mystied by her disappearance. The mystery of Trudie Adams’ disappearance is now the focus of ABCs latest true crime podcast Unravel , which examines how the case has remained unsolved for  yearsIts now suspected by some that police corruption that might have played a part in the case. Its never about the actual incidents themselves, its about the cover-up, a former police official said in the podcast.In the months after Trudie’s disappearance, a number of young women came forward to report sexual assaults and attempted abductions in the Mona Vale area.The women’s accounts took place over a period beginning in , and they reported being blindfolded, handcuffed, held at gunpoint and sexually assaulted. The Unravel podcast states that: The rapes were of such maniacal brutality that even now the police have refused to reveal details on or off the record.  According to a report from New South Wales police in , detectives believed something similar may have happened to Trudie. It is our belief she was kidnapped by two males and murdered, Detective Superintendent Beresford said at the time. As a result of our inquiries, we believe Trudies abduction was sexually-motivated. Furthermore, we suspect there are more victims of these two sexual predators who have not previously come forward to police. Police offered a , reward for information that would solve the case, to no avail. Tragically, Trudie’s mother Connie died  years after her daughter’s disappearance without ever finding out what happened to her. At the  inquest, Trudies father said his we had died of a broken heart.Unravels investigative journalists Ruby Jones and Nick Mercer hope they might find some answers for Trudies family and friends.

title: britains nuclear test heroes given
story: NewsBritains nuclear test heroes given fresh hope with order to investigate possible probe into birth abnormalitiesAfter a -year campaign the government will consider examining the genetic legacy of Britain’s nuclear weapons testsShareCommentsBySusie Bonace:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDefence Secretary Gavin Williamson "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDefence supremo Gavin Williamson has given fresh hope to Britain’s nuclear test heroes with potential research into the genetic defects that plague their families. Ministry of Defence officials have been ordered to investigate how the shocking rate of birth abnormalities among nuclear veteran children -  times higher than the normal population - could be researched. Labour deputy leader Tom Watson, who is campaigning for the survivors to get a medal, said: “This is a fantastic development. Veterans’ biggest worry is the health of their children, an estimated , of whom live with a shockingly high rate of illness and disability which has never been explained. “The battle now is to ensure that the MoD looks at these problems properly rather than sweep them under the scientic carpet.”  It is the first time in  years of campaigning that a government has considered examining the genetic legacy of Britain’s nuclear bomb tests, which took place in Australia and the South Pacic between  and . Veteran John Ward, , was an RAF typist at Christmas Island in  for five nuclear experiments. He has had bladder cancer, his son Mark has had kidney cancer, and he describes daughter Denise as “a medical mess”. She has problems with her teeth, pancreas, reproductive system, and calcium growths. John, of Chesterfield, Derbyshire, said: “This is encouraging news and a massive improvement on the MoD’s long-held position of obfuscation and denial. Us old soldiers are relying on Mr Williamson to keep his word.” The Defence Secretary also appears to have slapped down blundering civil servants trying to block a medal. We revealed in August that officials had insisted a gong might depend on proof they were irradiated. But such proof is held by the MoD, which admits its records are patchy and filled with mistakes.  Now in a letter to Mr Watson, veterans minister the Earl Howe has apologised for “the awkward language” and said it was “never the intention” to snub those who served at the tests, many of whom were on National Service. He went on to say the veterans claim “a real dference in rates of miscarriage and congenital defects in their children and grandchildren compared with others” but there were “challenges to rigorous evaluation of such questions”. Although two studies in  found evidence of genetic damage, birth defects and  times the normal rate of infant mortality among veterans’ children, not every miscarriage or abnormality used to be recorded as they are today. He said: “My officials have requested up to date expert advice on possible approaches which is presently awaited.” The minister added the veterans’ case was similar to that for the heroes of the Arctic Convoys, who finally won a medal in . Around , men were ordered to take part in the tests, and only , survive. One dies, on average, every week. To sign the petition for a nuclear medal click here .

title: jamal khashoggi former uk student
story: NewsFormer UK university student cut up Jamal Khashoggis body with bone saw while listening to music to drown out screamsDr. Salah al-Tubaigy, an autopsy expert who studied at Glasgow University in , was in a hit squad accused of torturing the journalist at the Saudi Arabia consulate in IstanbulShareCommentsByLisa TonerPeter Davidson:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDr. Salah Mohammed al-Tubaigy a forensic pathologist who specialises in autopsies and studied for a time at Glasgow University "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former UK student has been named as a suspect in the disappearance and torture of missing Saudi Arabian journalist. Jamal Khashoggi was last seen inside the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul earlier this month. Now, it has been revealed Dr. Salah al-Tubaigy, an autopsy expert who studied in Glasgow in , is reportedly one of the suspects in the hit squad accused of torturing and killing Mr. Khashoggi, according to the New York Times . Former advisor to the Saudi Arabian royal family, Jamal Khashoggi fell out of favour with the establishment and went into self-imposed exile. The renowned critic of the Saudi leadership, who also worked as a columnist for The Washington Post, was last seen entering the consulate on October  in order to get paperwork to marry his Turkish partner Hatice Cengiz, reports the Daily Record .  He hasnt been seen since. The Middle East Eye reported earlier today that a recording from an anonymous Turkish source captured audio taken from Mr. Khashoggis own apple watch.  The recording is said to reveal his final grim moments, in which he was dragged from the Saudi Consul General’s office onto a table in a next-door study, before he endured a horric seven-minute ordeal as he was butchered alive. The New York Times named Dr. Salah al-Tubaigy among  suspects so far identied by the Turkish authorities. The Times also names nine other high-ranking officials from the oil rich country who could have been part of the death squad involved in Jamal Khashoggis killing. Dr. Salah Al-Tubaigy identies himself on his Twitter account as head of the Saudi Scientic Council of Forensics.  He holds senior positions in the Saudi Interior Ministry and medical establishment, a figure of such stature that he could be directed only by a high-ranking Saudi authority, The New York Times writes. Turkish officials say they possess evidence that the  Saudi agents flew into Istanbul on Oct. , assassinated Mr. Khashoggi and dismembered his body with a bone saw within two hours of his arrival at the consulate. The are reported to have flown out the same day. Dr. Salah Al-Tubaigy was pictured at Istanbuls Ataturk airport on October , raising more suspicion around his involvement in the alleged torture case. He has not publicly addressed the allegations. None of the suspects could be reached for comment.

title: meghan harry taste australia indigenous
story: NewsMeghan and Harry get taste of Australia with indigenous cookery class - and kangaroo for lunchHarry and Meghan, a self-confessed foodie, visited the Charcoal Lane restaurant as they toured Melbourne on the third day of their visit Down UnderShareCommentsByRussell MyersAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video royal-couple-taste-native-australian-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Sussex was in her element as she and Prince Harry enjoyed a taste of Australia today.Self confessed foodie Meghan visited Charcoal Lane with her husband, a social enterprise restaurant in Melbourne’s trendy Fitzroy suburb.At a private lunch, the royal couple enjoyed a shared entree of mushroom and quinoa nest and chargrilled kangaroo and main courses of wild boar, saffron risotto and barramundi. It was prepared by young chefs being trained by the Mission Australia programme, which assists young indigenous Australians into employment, in many cases giving them a fresh start in le.  Before the meal, they visited the kitchen and met Executive Chef Greg Hampton. Harry joked: “You’ve got a very clean kitchen – is it always this clean  Especially clean today ” Meghan slipped off her Martin Grant trench coat in the warm room before Greg talked the couple through an array of unusual herbs and aromatic spices, getting them to smell and taste them.  “A lot of these ingredients have been here for thousands of years. Our fruits are the same as fruits thousands of years ago,” he explained. Showing them a finger lime, he squeezed out the fleshy contents, explaining: “It comes out like caviar.” “Oh my goodness, that’s incredible,” said the Duchess. But he warned the couple that the Tasmanian Pepper came with a kick, adding: “I don’t want to freak you out!”  Speaking ahead of their arrival, Greg said: “I would hesitate to offer [the pregnant Duchess] the pepper, because they are quite hot. “The first time I tasted one I thought I was having an allergic reaction because the heat creeps up on you. I don’t want to freak her out.” Crushing a leaf of Strawberry Gum, a type of Eucalyptus, he encouraged the royal visitors to smell it. “Is that what Koalas eat in the Bush ” asked the Duke. “Yes, but we can’t eat it in the same way,” replied Greg, explaining how oils from the plant are used to flavour marinades, fish dishes and even ice cream.  The couple was presented with Charcoal Lane aprons for the “touch, taste and smell” experience, but did not wear them. Speaking ahead of the royal visit, Greg said: “We are here to support young Aboriginal people into the workforce, with a view that when they leave this place, there is going to be long-term employment for them,” he said. “I’m not going to turn everyone that comes here into a chef, butthey leave here with a work ethic, it’s a win for us.” Charcoal Lane currently employs  young people for  hours a week as they work towards a Certicate  in hospitality. “A lot of them come from backgrounds where nobody has worked, so this is very important for them,” said Greg.  Programme Manager Troy Crellin said that in  years, the organisation had helped some  Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders into work. The Duke and Duchess’s visit to the restaurant began after they admired a mural outside created by Gunnai and Waradgerie man Robert Young to honour the building and the area’s indigenous heritage. He told Harry and Meghan how his Celebration Dreaming artwork references Aboriginal identity, connections and culture in inner Melbourne Fitzroy. Before heading into the kitchen, they received a Welcome to Country delivered by Wurundjeri Elder Uncle Colin Hunter. Mission Australia CEO, James Toomey said: “It was such a fantastic and humbling surprise to hear that Mission Australia’s restaurant, Charcoal Lane was chosen to welcome The Duke and Duchess for a tour, hands-on cooking session and lunch. It is a once in a letime opportunity for the students to meet Their Royal Highnesses. Not too many young people can say they’ve met and served royalty! “At Charcoal Lane, we are passionate about celebrating Aboriginal history and providing students with a culturally safe space to express their inidual identities and overcome any challenges they may face on their journey to employment. Our program not only provides training and real work for young locals, but also fosters a sense of cultural and community pride which we are proud to have shared with Their Royal Highnesses. “We also encourage locals and visitors to Melbourne to make a reservation at Charcoal Lane – there are not many places you can say you ate the same meal as the royal couple while also making a social dference.” FOR LIVE UPDATES ON THE ROYAL TOUR THROUGHOUT THE NIGHT - CLICK HERE The Duke and Duchess are currently touring Australia for the rest of this week, spending much of their time in Sydney. Yesterday, the royals visited Dubbo, around km outside of Sydney, before arriving in Melbourne, Victoria, today for another busy list of engagements. Their tour will also take in New Zealand as well as Fiji and Tonga. During this leg of their tour, Meghan has been banned from visiting the jungle to avoid the Zika virus endangering the baby. The virus is a “moderate” risk on both islands. A palace source said: “They sought out top medical advice.” The royal will be kept away from the rainforest on her first major international tour with Harry.  UK health authorities classy both Pacic islands as having a “moderate” risk of Zika, which can cause severe complications for unborn babies. With Meghan expecting her first child, announced as they arrived in Australia yesterday, she will go for tea with the British High Commissioner in Fiji as Harry treks in the rainforest. At a tea in Dubbo yesterday, Meghan enjoyed another tea with a farming family - even bringing her own banana bread to share after cooking it at Admiralty House the night before.  Meghan was also pictured getting stuck in feeding cows on the Mountain View farm. The Duke and Duchess visited the farm to learn about how severe drought has blighted farmers lives recently. Although ironically, the heavens opened during their visit, with Meghan pictured under an umbrella as the rain became heavy.

title: mum wants you see devastating
story: NewsMum wants you to see this devastating picture of her seriously ill four-year-old daughterAshleigh, mum of Edie Molyneux, from Tranmere, shared the image to Facebook showing her daughters plightShareCommentsByJenny Kirkham:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsEdie Molyneuxs mum Ashleigh posted this heartbreaking photo to Facebook"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has shared a devastating image of her daughter being treated for an aggressive brain tumour to show what she is going through. Ashleigh, mum of Edie Molyneux, posted the devastating image on Facebook in order to raise awareness of the condition.Edie, four, is battling Dfuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma , the Liverpool Echo reports.This is an aggressive, and ultimately fatal growth at the base of her brain. The tumour’s location in the centre of the brain means it cannot be surgically removed. And in the UK, chemotherapy is not an option because the levels needed to treat this tumour would poison the rest of the body. So little Edie has to travel all over the world with her family to receive treatment.Ashleighs post, on The Spider-Ede Appeal Facebook page, shows her crying in the foreground as her little girl lies on a hospital bed behind her, hooked to a ventilator. The status also told followers that Edie was doing amazing just yesterday before becoming limp and unresponsive.Mum-of-three, Ashleigh, from Tranmere , said: A picture speaks a thousand words.I have debated putting this photo up. Not because of how I look, that is so far from my concerns. But for fear people will shy away from seeing the real pain.  Yesterday Edie was doing AMAZING, almost off ventilation and taking so many breaths for herself. All of a sudden in the afternoon she started to breathe irregularly, we alerted the medics. The ventilator was turned up and she was given a check over. She had become limp and unresponsive. The doctors took her for a CT scan, the initial thought was that there may be a bleed on the brain. I never thought I’d say “unfortunately there is no bleed on the brain. The only visible culprit is the Tumour. Has it taken anotherfrom our baby   We just have to wait, there has still been no improvement. We pray for a miracle. Explaining why she decided to post the emotional photograph, Ashley said she wanted people to see the hurt the illness causes.  She said: So why did I take this photo  We need you to see the reality of this, the raw hurt it causes. On the exterior we know we look strong. But when nobody is looking, sometimes not even our family, this is the time our worries creep in and we crumble. All of the questions what  why  If  Looking back at the photo is so strange with the “happy” birthday decorations in the background. Just another reminder of how quickly things can change. Edie turned four earlier this week and her family and friends celebrated the exciting day with balloons and her favourite movies. In a post on Facebook Edies family said they were having a day of positivity to celebrate after a fundraising ball was held in her honour at the Hillbark Hotel in West Kirkby. The status was also accompanied by a picture of Edie in hospital with a Feliz Cumpleanos banner hung above her bed. It said: Today we will be filling the day with Edie’s favourites. The wonderful nurse in with Edie today hand made a birthday sign for the wall! Friends have visited and we will see more through the day! Thank you all for your wonderful love-filled messages, we have showered her with love and will do all day. Last nights birthday ball was amazing, we looked through photos and watched videos, playing them to Edie. A day of positivity, complete positivity! Happy Birthday Baby Girl! Finishing off todays heart-wrenching post, Ashleigh said: Please send Edie all of your prayers and positivity. Only she can step up her game right now and push back. She has done it before! We believe in her and we believe in God. You can donate to the Spider-Ede appeal via this JustGiving linkor by texting EDIE pound to .

title: veal calves trying suckle peoples
story: NewsVeal calves trying to suckle on peoples hands for comfort endure tortuous journey from Scotland to be slaughtered in SpainSome of them were barely two weeks old - live animal exports cannot be banned under EU freedom of movement of goods rulesShareCommentsByAndrew Penman:,  OCT NewsCalves in a truck at Ramsgate "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter a journey of more than  miles, a truck load of calves were loaded onto a ferry last night for export to the continent.Outraged protestors who watched the shipment included Lilibet Marsh of the group Kent Animal Save , which monitors live animal exports from the port of Ramsgate.Her pictures posted on social media show the ear tags of the cattle, revealing that some were born as recently as October . “These were unweaned calves, they were desperately trying to suckle on peoples hands for comfort, they were very distressed,” she said. “I was only alerted to them because I could hear them crying from the other side of the car park.”  Replies to her post included “Disgusting and a complete horror for them and heartbreaking for us,” and “We have been told these shipments will be at least two a month of at least two lorries, we must make a stand and stop this now.” The animals began their journey at a farm in Dumfries and Galloway in Scotland. “This is a new low and campaigners at Ramsgate are shocked because this has not happened from Ramsgate for a long time,” said Lorraine Platt of the Conservative Animal Welfare Foundation. “The calves are around two weeks old and bound for veal farms in Spain. “We must end this vile trade - as we did with veal crates and sow stalls.” The export of calves and veal crates became a cause ceacutelegravebre in the mid s, with demonstrators blocking ports in protest at the suffering endured by animals on long cramped journeys with insufficient heating, food and water.I told earlier this month how three truck loads of live sheep were exported from Ramsgate on a converted open-deck former Russian tank transport ferry.The RSPCA has branded the export of live animals for fattening and slaughter abroad “ unacceptable and unnecessary ” and says that they are sometimes taken to countries were they are kept in conditions that would be illegal in this country.The trade cannot be legally banned under EU freedom of movement of goods rules.  “Brexit provides an unprecedented opportunity to bring about an end to this cruel and needless trade and consign live exports to the history books,” said David Bowles, RSPCA head of public affairs, last October. “The RSPCA believes that the UK has two options when it comes to live transport. “Firstly, it could ban the live export of farm animals for slaughter alone, or even for further fattening. Secondly it could impose journey time limits on transport once the animals had left UK territory. “Both are not possible until the UK leaves the EU. “Were confident that a live export ban or a restriction upon export journeys could be acceptable to the World Trade Organistion, now that a clear framework has been established to ensure regulations can be crafted so they can pass the tests set at the WTO.”

title: americans being tricked voting clever
story: NewsAmericans are being tricked into voting with clever clickbait - and its geniusSome Twitter users just care way more about the Kardashians than they do about politicsShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsThe midterms are coming up "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRegistering to vote is so important - but its amazing how many people dont bother doing it. The fact is, its hard to get people to care about politics. It can be confusing and hard to know what to believe, so some people just switch off. Something lots of us do care about is celebrity break ups and people in the US have come up with a genius way of tapping into that to encourage voter registrations. By using clickbait news stories or sensational headlines about celebrities, social media users are fooling people into visiting vote.org in the hope that theyll register for the upcoming midterm elections - genius.  Some brilliant examples include: Wow I can’t believe this is why Ariana Grande and Pete Davidson split up Someone  posted the link with: omg i can’t believe this is the REAL reason kanye is in Uganda. Another tricked people with this: GUYS ONE DIRECTION IS GETTING BACK TOGETHER!!!!! Its a really smart way of getting people to the website where they can register to vote.However, using deception on social media is controversial, more so since Facebook was accused of allowing Cambridge Analytica to harvest the details of its users for Trumps presidential campaigning in .This trend appears to have originated from a tweet by writer Ashlee Marie Preston, who used the link in a post about Kim Kardashian orcing Kanye.She wrote: Welp...it’s official...Kim Kardashian finally decided to orce Kanye West... The link has been clicked on more than  million times, which is no insignicant number when it comes to votes. Whether or not those two million people actually registered or not is unknown, but it proves that this kind of tactic could potentially work.  Despite its effectiveness in getting people to click through to the vote.org website, peoples opinions are ided on the technique. Some thought the idea was awesome, with one writing that its a sneaky and ingenious idea. Others thought it was annoying and unfair. Several people commented to say that the tactic actually worked on them. Maybe well have to try something similar in the UK...

title: one eyed cat makes incredible
story: NewsOne-eyed cat makes an incredible -mile journey from Hull to Bristol – clinging to bottom of lorryThe fearless tom named Lucy is known for wandering off, but this might be his most ambitious adventure yetShareCommentsByStephen White:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLucy the miracle tomcat travelled over  miles in the chassis of a lorry trailer "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA one-eyed male cat called Lucy is on his way home – after a perilous -mile journey stuck under an articulated lorry. The -year-old tomcat was discovered by workers at a kitchen distribution depot on the edge of Bristol. The lorry driver who had just travelled from a depot near Hull, initially thought Lucy was dead. She was unresponsive between the rear wheel arches of the trailer. Worker Dan Cartwright said: “The driver said ‘I think I hit and killed an animal, there’s something in there’, so we went to look. “We thought he was dead and then, suddenly, he lted up his head, so we called the RSPCA.”  Lucy was microchipped, giving the RSPCA a clue about where exactly in the country he had stowed away on board. Owner Paul Smith, of Goole, East Yorks, said: “He’s often going off and disappearing for a couple of days...“The first I knew he’d gone a bit further than normal was an appeal on Facebook . “I was absolutely over the moon to discover he had been safely found.” Paul said his mum originally called the cat Lucy and the name had stuck

title: jamal khashoggi everything know saudi
story: NewsJamal Khashoggi: Everything we know about Saudi journalist murdered and cut up alive by hit squadMr Khashoggi vanished after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey, on October  - heres all we know so far about the caseShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news article.ece,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi has been missing for  days.Mr Khashoggi, a critic of the Saudi leadership, was last seen entering the countrys consulate in Istanbul, Turkey, on October . Turkish officials have said they have recorded evidence that he was assassinated by a -strong hit squad who flew in on a private jet.They believe his body was then removed - with one Turkish source claiming the -year-old was chopped up on a table while still alive.But the Saudis have strongly denied the allegations, insisting that Mr Khashoggi left the consulate safely on the day he was last seen. Below, we look at all we know so far about the case.  Who is Jamal Khashoggi  Mr Khashoggi is a US resident and Washington Post columnist who was critical of the Saudi government, calling for reforms. He had worked at the Saudi embassies in Washington, US, and London, and was well-liked by both fellow journalists and diplomats. He was described by one as a warm and funny man.According to Dexter Filkins, writing for The New Yorker , he was also loyal to his principles and refused to compromise his values.This prompted the Saudi government, in , to silence him, claims Dexter, adding that Mr Khashoggi fled to the US last year.  In a move made after Mohammed Bin Salman became Saudi Arabias Crown Prince, the respected journalist relocated to Virginia.There, he penned Washington Post columns and became a prominent critic of Bin Salman, the New York Timesreports.He was engaged to a Turkish woman when he disappeared.Why was he at the Saudi consulate  Mr Khashoggi, a orcee, was caught on CCTV footage arriving at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on October . He was visiting the building to obtain marriage documents that would enable him to wed his Turkish fianceacutee. He entered the consulate via its main entrance. His fianceacutee, Hatice Cengiz, who waited outside, said he never re-appeared.  What happened during his visit  There are conflicting claims over what happened at the consulate. Turkish officials have said they believe Mr Khashoggi was murdered and his body removed - an allegation the Saudis have strongly denied. This week, a Turkish source claimed the journalist was cut up alive by a hit squad - who listened to music while dismembering his body. The source, who has allegedly listened to an audio recording of the reporters last moments, said it took seven minutes for him to die.They had come to kill him,” they told Middle East Eye .Mr Khashoggi was allegedly dragged from the Consul General’s office into his study next door, where he was dumped on a table.  Loud screams could then be heard - which only stopped when he was injected with an unknown substance, according to the source. Moments later, his body was allegedly cut up by the squad.According to a report by the NYT , the journalists body is said to have been dismembered with a bone saw brought by the suspects.Saudi officials have denied any involvement in the journalists disappearance, which has made headlines across the world. However, reports have claimed they are preparing a report saying he was killed during an attempt to bundle him out of the consulate. The case has provoked an international outcry against Saudi Arabia, the worlds top oil exporter, with more media and business executives pulling out of a planned investment conference there this month.  Are there any suspects  Turkey has identied  suspects in the alleged murder - including forensic evidence expert Salah Muhammad al-Tubaigy. The MEE source claimed that Mr Tubaigy listened to music via a set of earphones as he chopped up the reporters body. And he allegedly advised his accomplices to do the same. When I do this job, I listen to music. You should do [that] too, Mr Tubaigy said in the audio recording, according to the source. At least nine of the suspects worked for the Saudi security services, military or other government ministries, according to the NYT.  It is alleged they flew out the same day as the killing, and brought the bone saw with them for the purpose of cutting up Mr Khashoggis body. Records allegedly show that two private jets chartered by a Saudi firm arrived and departed from Istanbul on October . The latest claims follow US media reports that Saudi Arabia will admit the vanished journalist died following a botched interrogation. What does Donald Trump say US President Donald Trump earlier sensationally gave Saudi Arabia the benefit of the doubt in Mr Khashoggis disappearance.US lawmakers have pointed the finger at the Saudi leadership, while Western pressure has mounted on Riyadh to provide answers. In an interview with Fox Business Network, Mr Trump saidSaudi Arabia knew what happened in the disappearance, that would be bad. I think we have to find out what happened first, he said yesterday.  Speaking to reporters, he also drew comparisons with the Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court scandal, adding: Here we go again with, you know, youre guilty until proven innocent. I dont like that. Mr Trump had earlier posted a Tweet saying that Bin Salman denied knowing what happened in the Saudi consulate. The president has suggested that rogue killers could have been involved in the case. However, such a move without sanction from the Saudi regime is believed to be highly unlikely by many. And how about Turkey  Today, Turkeys foreign minister said the country hoped to enter the Saudi consuls residence in connection with the case. Turkish police had been expected to search the building yesterday. However, they did not do so, officers at the scene said last night, because Saudi officials were not able to join them. Hours earlier, the consul general left Turkey for Riyadh. Yesterday evening, unfortunately, police could not search the Saudi consuls residence, Mevlut Cavusoglu told reporters today after meeting US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in Ankara.  He added: We hope the police will enter to the residence today. We have said before that Saudi Arabia must cooperate with us in every aspect without delay. Mr Cavusoglu, who said the search would extend to the consuls vehicles, said the consul was free to travel home and had not been deported. He also said talks with Mr Pompeo were beneficial and fruitful. Mr Pompeo was on a brief visit to Turkey after having met with the Saudi king, crown prince and foreign minister in Riyadh yesterday. Turkish crime scene investigators had carried out a nine-hour search of the consulate on Monday night as part of the probe. Last Saturday, a Turkish newspaper reported that recordings made on Mr Khashoggis Apple Watch - had been uncovered by investigators.  These recordings allegedly indicated he was tortured and killed, but the report in the Sabah daily could not immediately be veried. “The moments when Khashoggi was interrogated, tortured and murdered were recorded in the Apple Watch’s memory,” the paper said. It added that the watch had synched with the journalists iPhone, which his fiancee was carrying outside the consulate. However, technology experts have said it is highly unlikely the watch could have recorded actions inside the embassy and uploaded them to an iCloud account. And the Saudis  Saudi officials have denied any involvement in Mr Khashoggis disappearance and have claimed he left the consulate safely. After meeting with King Salman and the crown prince yesterday, Mr Pompeo told reporters that Saudi Arabia has committed to conducting a complete investigation into the case. In each of those meetings I stressed the importance of them conducting a complete investigation into the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, he told reporters.  They made a commitment to do that. He added: They said it would be a thorough, complete and transparent investigation. They indicated they understood that getting that done in a timely, rapid fashion so they could begin to answer important questions. Asked whether they said Mr Khashoggi was alive or dead, Mr Pompeo said: They didnt talk about any of the facts. Last Thursday, Turkey said it and Saudi Arabia had agreed to form a joint working group - at Riyadh’s initiative - to investigate the case. A Saudi source said a senior royal, Prince Khaled al-Faisal, had visited Turkey that day.  And the following day, SPA said that Saudi Arabia’s interior minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Saud bin Na, condemned the “lies and baseless allegations” against the kingdom. However, he apparently praised the joint investigation with Turkey. Has the UK issued a statement  Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt and his G counterparts have said they are very troubled by Mr Khashoggis disappearance. They have insisted those responsible must be held to account. In an earlier statement, the G foreign ministers said: We, the G foreign ministers, of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, and the High Representative of the European Union, affirm our commitment to defending freedom of expression and protection of a free press.  We remain very troubled by the disappearance of prominent Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Those bearing responsibility for his disappearance must be held to account. We encourage Turkish-Saudi collaboration and look forward to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia conducting a thorough, credible, transparent, and prompt investigation, as announced. Mr Hunt has said previously that questions remain about the case that only Saudi Arabia can answer. On Monday, Prime Minister Theresa May’s spokesman said Britain expected the Saudi government to provide a detailed response to questions over Mr Khashoggis disappearance. “We expect the Saudi government to provide a complete and detailed response,” the spokesman told reporters.  What do Mr Khashoggis relatives say  In a heartbreaking statement released on Monday, members of Mr Khashoggis family called for an investigation. We are sadly and anxiously following the conflicting news regarding the fate of our father after losing contact with him two weeks ago, they said. The strong moral and legal responsibility which our father instilled in us obliges us to call for the establishment of an independent and impartial international commission to inquire into the circumstances of his death.

title: as it happens partick thistle v dundee united
story: Robbie Neilson#s reign as Dundee United boss gets under way today with a trip to Firhill as they take on Partick Thistle.

title: celtic defender jack hendry believes ex club dundee can rise again
story: Former Dundee defender Jack Hendry has backed the Dark Blues to haul themselves off the foot of the Premiership table.The Celtic centre-back played the full  minutes in Scotland’s - friendly defeat to Portugal at Hampden on Sunday evening.However, when asked about the fortunes of his former club, who sit bottom of the Premiership pile, the -year-old was bullish in his assertion they “definitely” have what it takes to climb up the league.“I haven’t seen much of Dundee’s games to be fair but, obviously, sometimes they’ve been struggling to pick up results that maybe they’ve deserved to get and get a few points in.“That part of it will be a frustration for themselves but I’d like to see them do well.“They’ve, obviously, got the ability in their squad to get out of the position they’re in and, hopefully, they can do that.”Scotland fell to defeat in Glasgow’s south side against the European Champions with Hendry and Kirriemuir native Scott McKenna at the heart of the home rearguard.They shipped three goals, one more than their team-mates did against Israel last Thursday in their - Nations League loss in Haa.However, Hendry believes they didn’t disgrace themselves after Steven Naismith notched with the last kick of the game to cancel out earlier goals from Helder Costa, Eder and Bruma for the Portuguese.He added: “I don’t think there was much in it. I thought it was a good performance, especially in the first half.“It didn’t feel like a - defeat, so it was a bit disappointing coming off with that scoreline but it was good to get the goal at the end.”The former Partick Thistle and Wigan centre-half has been pleased with his own progress in the blue of Scotland lately after picking up his third cap.He hopes that, alongside defensive partner McKenna, there are many more to come in the months and years ahead as Alex McLeish’s side look to get their Nations League campaign back on track as they travel to Albania and Israel come to Hampden next month.“In my first two caps I think I played very well and again last night, apart from near the end where I gave the ball away and it led to a goal, I thought I had a solid performance.“I’m taking everything in my stride, trying to keep learning and, hopefully, building on it. Scott’s a talented player and it’s good to see that kind of talent coming through the Scotland ranks. We work well as a partnership and we work well with each other so, hopefully, that can grow.“With the facilities, the coaching staff and the players around you at Celtic and with Scotland you’re always going to kick on as long as you put the work in, which I’m doing. So, hopefully, I can keep improving.”

title: dundee council officers back plans to turn ex factory into 57 affordable homes
story: City councillors are being asked to approve plans to turn a dilapidated factory site in Dundee into a new affordable housing scheme.Cullross Limited and Caledonia Housing Association have submitted a joint planning application to Dundee City Council to regenerate the former Maxwelltown Works on Alexander Street, in the Hilltown area.The proposed scheme, designed by JMA Architects, would involve the construction of  rented and low-cost homes, consisting of one and two-bedroom flats and two, three and four-bedroom homes.The council’s new executive director of city development Robin Presswood will recommend to members of the planning committee on Monday night that they approve the plans.In his report to go before the committee, Mr Presswood said: “The application is for a contemporary development of  units comprising of  dwelling houses and  flats with associated roads, parking, footpaths and landscaping at Maxwelltown Works,“The site is an allocated brownfield housing site in the local development plan.“As the proposed number of residential units is more than , the proposals constitute a major planning application.“The proposed development is in accordance with the development plan and is recommended for approval.”The recommendation for approval is subject to  planning conditions, including that details of the proposed finishing material should be submitted to the council before work starts.Another condition states that street lighting and drainage plans must also be agreed in advance.

title: dundee fc manager neil mccann leaves club after board try to bring in new assistant
story: Dundee have tonight parted company with manager Neil McCann.It is understood that matters were brought to a head over the club#s desire to bring in an assistant to replace assistant manager Graham Gartland.A statement released this evening confirms that Gartland will also depart.It said: #The club can confirm that manager Neil McCann has today left the club.#We have explored alternative options to support the management staff recently but unfortunately these did not come to fruition.#Neil was appoint interim manager in April  and steered the club clear of relegation with five matches of the   season remaining.#In the summer he was appointed as manager of the club and in his first full season with the club achieved a th place finish with highlights in the season including a victory over Dundee United in the Betfred Cup and Rangers in the Ladbrokes Premiership.#This season after progression from the Betfred Cup group stage a run of defeats in the league came to the end with a win over Hamilton Accies at the end of September.#The following week the team were beaten at home to Kilmarnock.#We would like thank Neil and Graham for their efforts while in charge and wish them all the best for the future.#

title: dundee fc manager two horse race between jim mcintyre and gordon strachan
story: Bookies say Jim McIntyre and Gordon Strachan are in a two-horse race to succeed Neil McCann in charge of Dundee.McCann left the club last night after a wretched start to the season comprising one win and seven defeats in the Premiership.The final straw was a row over who should be McCann#s assistant, with the club demanding a more experienced No .Although managing director John Nelms is yet to comment publicly on who will replace McCann, bookmaker McBookie has installed Jim McIntyre as the overwhelming favourite at  .McIntyre has considerable experience from his time in charge at Dunfermline, Queen of the South and Ross County, where he lted the League Cup.He’s been out of a job since being sacked by the Staggies in September last year and was approached by Dundee United earlier this month prior to their appointment of Robbie Neilson.Second favourite for the Dundee hot seat at   is Gordon Strachan, who began his career at Dens Park in the s.The -year-old has had a year out of management since resigning as Scotland manager but his wage expectations # he was on a seven-figure annual salary while in charge of the national side # may prove a big stumbling block.Next on the list at   is ex Rangers star Kenny Miller, who moved to Dens Park as a player in August  after a seven-week spell as player-manager of Livingston # Dundee#s next opponents this Saturday.Miller, , is thought to be keen to continue playing, which may prove an issue for Nelms and the Dundee board.Ian McCall, Alan Stubbs and Barry Smith have been installed at  , with Jim Jefferies , Maurice Ross and Stephen Pressleyalso in the frame.Dundee FC manager Neil McCann LEAVES Dens after club try to bring in new assistant" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-fc-manager-neil-mccann-leaves-club-after-board-try-to-bring-in-new-assistant embed # title: dundee people buying business no dizzy decision
story: In less than a year Kash Piechocki bought her own shop and developed a beauty business which is now thriving.On November  last year Kash bought a beauty salon – Dizzys – which would go on to become a tribute to her mum.When I asked when her career in beauty began, the surprising answer was, November  last year.Kash explained: “I sadly lost my mum and she had left money for me.“I had always been in to art and she was always telling me to go and do something creative but I never listened to her and had just worked in admin roles for ious businesses.“When the premises at Whitehall Crescent came up for sale I just thought, I am going to use this money to make my own business and that is what I have done.”Kash undertook an eyelash course in December and from then she has built up a strong clientele and her own team of self employed beauticians who offer everything from lash extensions to nails and brow treatments.They also offer a range of facials with a new Dermaplaning treatment on offer.But this shop isn’t like most other beauty salons. Kash prides herself on doing things a bit dferently.She added: “We are dead open, dead real and we don’t follow suit.“I hated going into beauty salons as I thought I was being judged for not being just like them. I never wanted anyone to feel like that coming into my shop.“I say we aren’t a beauty salon, we are a beauty shop – just like a barber shop vibe.“The competition in this industry is crazy but we have clients coming from far and wide including Fe and Blairgowrie, so we must be doing something right.”Eyelashes and brows aren’t the only things Kash hopes to offer in the future, she is also halfway through her tattoo apprenticeship and is looking to offer her skills when it is complete.She also sells her art in the shop and does commissions for tattoo artwork.Although Kash admits it is a   job running your own business she says anyone wanting to follow a similar path should “just do it”.She added: “If you want something go for it, but do your research first.“I am so happy with Dizzys and know my mum would be so proud of it too.”The hottest new treatment at Dizzys is a Dermaplaning facial carried out by Erin Abbott.The facial uses a sterile surgical scalpel to shave the surface of the skin to reduce excess dead skin and peach fuzz hairs.The tool is held at a -degree angle and is brushed along the skin to remove the hair and skin cells leaving your skin baby soft.I tried it out myself and wow, what a dference it has made.The procedure was pain free and a face mask after gave me  minutes of relaxing bliss.The treatment promises to make your make up sit flawlessly and I can’t wait to put a full face on to see the dference.Erin said: “All of our clients have had glowing feedback and it is great giving them the confidence of new skin.”

title: dundee people hoping to follow in murrays footsteps

title: sunderland target glen kamara could be bound for euros after scoring first finland goal
story: Dundee midfielder Glen Kamara could be on his way to the next Euros after helping Finland to another impressive victory.Kamara’s last-minute goal on Monday night – his first for his country – clinched a - victory over Greece in the Ratina Stadium in Tampere.It leaves the Finns with a perfect record after four games and just needing a single point from their final two matches to confirm they’ll top their four-team group.The -year-old – linked with Sunderland at the weekend – came on as a second half sub in a - win over Estonia on Friday night before getting the full  minutes against the Greeks.As well as more than playing his part in helping his nation to their latest successes, that game time should be of benefit to Dundee.Kamara, last season’s star man at Dens Park, has been struggling with an ankle problem since July.He has been back for the Dark Blues’ last three league outings and will have benefited from the extra action while most of his clubmates were having the weekend off.Kamara will be back in time to complete preparations for Saturday’s trip to face in-form Livingston, as should Benjamin Kallman.The striker has also been back in Finland, with their U  squad.They are due in European Championship action against Lithuania tonight.The -year-old wasn’t involved when the Finns, who have no chance of qualying, went down in a home clash with Georgia at the end of last week.

title: tom duthie dundee united fans right to be smiling at clubs new beginning
story: If there’s a group of fans in the country who don’t need warned about  dawns, it has to be those at Dundee United.Since their team was relegated the best part of two-and-a-half years ago, Arabs have seen things look good for a time under Ray McKinnon and the same thing repeated under Csaba Laszlo.In the months that followed, however, optimism turned to frustration as the Tangerines went reasonably close to promotion back to the Premiership, but ultimately failed to secure it.Particularly in the case of McKinnon, that was not all his fault, and with hindsight he should probably have been given more time to get United back up to the top ision.That’s a story for another day as now the focus among fans is very much on how Robbie Neilson, their club’s fth manager in three years, is going to do.Past early promise that led to heartache, however, is why, despite an excellent opening victory against Partick Thistle at Firhill on Saturday, many will remain cautious and not yet be getting carried away about what the new gaffer is going to achieve.That’s understandable and right, because never mind once, this is a case of twice bitten, third time shy.Fans have the right to wait for events of the coming months to unfold before decidingNeilson, while without question the obvious choice as manager, is indeed the man to lead United back to the Premiership.What they can be is encouraged by the start he made at Thistle. For the first time in a while, there was a spark and energy about the team that suggests they have the quality to mount a strong and successful promotion challenge.Having suggested that, through no fault of Neilson or his players, this was maybe not the best game on which to judge them.While United’s play for most of the proceedings was excellent, there is no doubt in Thistle they were facing a beleaguered outfit that looks to still be coming to terms with a relegation.Two games against the Tangerines this season have seen them well-beaten and fortunate the margin of their defeats were not considerably greater. They are in the process of finding a new manager to replace Alan Archibald and it’s clear the man who comes in has a very big job on his hands.As the old adage goes, however, Neilson and his players could only beat what was put in front of them and in his first game in charge victory was achieved in some style.And aspects of the performance mean Arabs do have good reason to feel optimistic about their team’s prospects.After just a few days working with the new boss, Saturday saw a United team that looked reinvigorated and one that, apparently, had a clear idea of what the game plan was. Too often that was not the case under his predecessor Laszlo.That produced a top performance and fine inidual displays, not least from man-of-the-match Paul McMullan.Less than two months ago it appeared his time at Tannadice could be up. On the evidence of his display at Thistle, the former Scotland U  could now be ready to show why McKinnon battled so hard to get him.Andthe work he, and others, did on the ball gave plenty of reason to look forward to the games that lie ahead, so too did the ferocious way the entire team battled to get it back when Partick had possession.Particularly under Laszlo, opposing teams were given too much time in possession, but now United look like a side that will get the ball back quickly.It’s why, while not getting ahead of themselves, United fans can again feel hopeful about their team.

title: Book festival organisers blown away by participant numbers
story: THOUSANDS of children took part in a mass reading event to set a new record for an Inverness book festival.A total of  primary pupils across the region read ndash or were read to ndash at the same time to launch NessBookFest which featured a broad programme of almost  free events over four days.Festival committee member and organiser Barbara Henderson was delighted with the numbers taking part in the read-in."We were blown away by the response," she said. "Our previous record was only in the high hundreds. This has been fantastic."It was the third running of the annual festival and among those taking part were Inverness-born award-winning author Ali Smith and crime writer Stuart MacBride.Festival chairwoman Alicia Socas was thrilled with the eventrsquos success."We are delighted with the buzz NessBookFest has generated this year and our committee is already really excited to plan another fantastic NessBookFest for ," she said.Venues included Inverness Town House, the central library and Waterstones bookshop in the Eastgate Shopping Centre as well as Highland Print Studio, the Velocity cafeacute, Artysanrsquos cafeacute, the former Dunbar Hospital and the Bike Shed in Merkinch.Events also took place at the childrenrsquos unit in Raigmore Hospital.Thursday  Oct  : AM

title: Bright future for aspiring farmers
story: A HIGHLAND school is the first to welcome a new project that aims to inspire and develop future entrepreneurs in farming.Nairn Academy launched the initiative at a garden party at the school to show off their new equipment and garden space following a tie-up with the Farmer Jones Academy .Local farmer Richard Jones created the social enterprise in a bid to tackle the dwindling numbers of young people pursuing a career in farming.The pupils have planted ious fruits and vegetables including carrots, lettuce, cabbage, strawberries and raspberries. The produce will help sustain a cafeacute the school wants to open.It is working with the Highland Council on the Beach Cafeacute project which would be run by S- pupils. Some younger pupils would also get the chance to help.The cafeacute is not finished yet, painting needs to be done and a fridge needs to be fitted which will take place during the October holidays.It is hoped the cafeacute will be up and running by Christmas.It will be open to school pupils and staff initially butit is a success it could open to the wider community.Nairn Academy and FJA are now working to introduce farming to the curriculum, with FJA providing polytunnels and other growing equipment to the school.Deputy head teacher Sarah Abenheimer said: "The Farmer Jones Academy at Nairn Academy Growing Project is an exciting new strand in our curriculum."Across S- it provides pupils with an insight into sustainability and the link between produce and plate. Further up the school, senior pupils are completing the Princersquos Trust -plus Achieve Programme, using the project for the enterprise unit."Pupils from S- have all taken part in making the garden what it is today and we look forward to seeing them all reap the benefits, of future harvest and wider career opportunities."Nairn Academy is assisting FJA in getting modules accredited for a iety of qualications which pupils can take to potential employers.Mr Jones said: "A passion for Scottish farming, food and drink and a desire to share that enthusiasm with youngsters led us to set up the Farmer Jones Academy."With invaluable support from Highland Councilrsquos Carbon Clever team and FirstPort social enterprise funding, we laid the foundations and are growing to be a fully-fledged community interest company."As a result, we have gone ahead with our schools work to encourage the next generation of food and drink entrepreneurs to find a positive career path they may not have considered before."The staff at Nairn Academy have been extremely supportive and helpful in helping us achieve our vision."By the end of the course pupils will have learned a iety of new skills such as designing and developing their own fresh food produce and will have learned about other start-up businesses and their selling points, values and marketing strategies.The project is supported by local employability group Developing the Young Workforce Inverness and Central Highland .Andy Maxtone, DYWICH programme manager, said: "The agriculture and food and drink industries are all prominent areas of employment in the region, and we applaud the Farmer Jones Academy for providing the opportunity for young people to get skilled up ahead of leaving education."The programme will provide CV boosting skills that will see pupils stand out when it comes to le after school ndash whatever career they choose to progress."Thursday  Oct  : AM
