title: ayrshire student launches campaign against
story: NewsAyrshire student launches campaign against spikingCara’s drive to keep young women safer when they’re out on the town.ShareByPippa Smith:,  OCT NewsCara Taven has launched a Facebook page named Girls Against Spiking. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA campaign has been set up to raise awareness of people having their drinks spiked. Cara Taven, from Coylton, set up a Facebook page called ‘Girls Against Spiking’to bring to light the effects of spiking on nights out and to, hopefully, eradicate it. The Facebook page, which has gained a following of over  people in one week, hopes to attract the attention of nightclubs and bars and is aiming for lids to be put on all drinks served at their bars as part of a drive to stop people having their drinks spiked.  Cara, , told the Post about her campaign. She said: “I have heard a lot about people getting spiked recently, in my local area and in the Glasgow region, and I know that a lot of people in Ayr do go out in Glasgow. “It tends to be younger girls about my age that get affected by spiking and that was something I have really started to think about. “This is something that could happen to anyone. “I’m a law student and the reason why I wanted to study law was to represent people who maybe don’t have the confidence to represent themselves and to make a dference that way and I think that is where getting the idea to make the page has come from. “I honestly thought it would be a page where the girls at my work could like – I am surprised by the response. “I remember saying to someone at work ‘If you like the page it’ll take me to  likes’ – then when I woke up in the morning and it was . “I haven’t been affected by spiking – it’s not really about me or anyone that I know. It is about the community of girls my age. “ I just felt like the answer was there and no one has done anything about it until now.” The Post reported how Cleo Smillie, , from Ayr, was on a night out in Madrid with her friend, Marc Davies, when she blacked out after one sip of her pink gin and lemonade. It was later learned that she had a high level of GHB in her blood – the date-rape drug. Strathclyde Union is among the nightclubs and bars that were prompted by the campaign and have gone on to order  lids on a trial basis as they work on ways to keep students as safe as possible on nights out.

title: bob shields latest column golf
story: Jim Ronneyleft and Russ Stewart ."Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLess than a year ago – in this very column – I argued the case for an Ayrshire coastal “commission” that would monitor every development that might affect our precious shoreline. An astute, respected and independent body, its remit would be to act for the long term greater good of the Ayrshire coast and its stakeholders - and issue unorm guidelines to prevent North, East and South Ayrshire councils peppering our seascapes with all kinds of piecemeal shoreline developments. Sadly, such a badly-needed supervisory power is still only a figment of my imagination. But had it existed – it would have poured over builder McCarthy and Stone’s ‘Legoland’ plans for the former Malcolm Sargent House site at Prestwick . . . before hobbing them into the nearest bin! As it is, neighbouring Prestwick Golf Club have taken the legal ‘ last resort’ and petitioned for a judicial review of South Ayrshire Council’s decision to grant planning approval. Successfully overturning SAC’s November  decision is the legal equivalent of holing a  footer on Prestwick’s th green. Only six per cent of inidual judicial reviews succeed. But they can take comfort in the classic  judicial review when planning permission for wind turbines was challenged because they were in the flight path of ospreys nesting hundreds of miles away! Lord Hope ruled that while no inidual with land interests had objected to the turbines, the “natural environment” is everyone’s interest. He memorably pronounced: “The osprey has no means of protecting itself. If its interests are to be protected, someone needs speak on its behalf”. Prestwick’s Golf Club’s members are scattered across the county, the country and the world. Not a single one of them has inidual land interests affected by the proposed development. But the  Tom Morris designed links - its fairways, dunes, greens, unique location, backcloth, traditions and history - cannot protect itself. In the spirit of Lord Hope’s ruling, its members are “speaking on its behalf”. And I say good luck to them. As I also said, their chances on paper are slim. Butit hits the Court of Session, and the man in the big seat has a Royal and Ancient tie under his robe – or bits of Muirfield on the golf shoes in the boot of his Jag - well . . . you just never know! Prestwick’s members are no fools either – they hope their legal move will get everyone back around the table for complete rethink on the scale of McCarthy and Stone’s plans. The builder will no doubt deny any adverse reflection on Prestwick – but you can bet the proximity of the historic links will be in the first paragraph in any of their sales brochures! McCarthy and Stone made a pound million profit in . Their average UK apartment price is almost pound, - and they’re planning  of them at Prestwick . . . that’s pound. million. With those numbers at stake – McCarthy and Stone will be putting all kinds of pressure on South Ayrshire Council not to cave in. Prestwick Golf Club doesn’t have a problem with the site being developed – but rightly ask that any development be appropriate in design and scale to its noble and historic surroundings. And that’s something McCarthy and Stone can easily afford. Prestwick Golf Club is a legendary place for winners. And there will be legendary amounts of Kummel quaffed in the clubhousethey win this one!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilEnvironmentPrestwickAirAsiaAyr

title: chief inspector makes return south
story: NewsChief inspector makes ato South AyrshireChief Inspector Derek Frew takes over the reigns from Gary I’Anson.ShareByPippa Smith:,  OCT NewsChief Inspector Derek Frew "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe new chief inspector in South Ayrshire has vowed to put the community at the heart of policing. Derek Frew has been announced as the new Area Commander for South Ayrshire Police. The -year-old takes over the reigns from Gary I’Anson. Having joined the police service in June  and been serving for  years, chief inspector Frew started off his probation in Ardrossan, Saltcoats and Stevenston.Ayrshire student launches campaign against spikingThe dad-of-two then went on to work in the communities across Ayrshire, most notably as the local bobby in Millport, where he lived from  to  with his we and two sons. In recent years, he has worked on national policing reform and been part of the Corporate Communications department. Before taking up his new post, he worked for the Scottish Multi-Agency Resilience, Training and Exercise Unit . Speaking to the Post, the chief inspector, declared: “Since I left school I had always wanted to join the police - with my traditional up bringing, I wanted to be part of the community. “As an operational officer, I have always worked in Ayrshire - when I first joined I started in the three towns, finished my probation and then moved to Millport as the local bobby. “It was an interesting but good experience - my family were young at the time - it was a Hamish MacBeth lestyle where I had the house that was built on to the police station. “What you learn at that point when you’re working yourself is in the winter you are working with your local community, but when you’re working throughout the summer time, you have the tourists - this is when the island community went from  upto , a day and you are still working yourself with the help of special constables. This is when you learn your people skills. I was there for three and a half years - you involve yourself with the community - it was just amazing. “It was a highlight for personal reasons, for family reasons, for friends you make for le and for the grounding it gives you in getting to know people. “I came back to Ayr in  as an operational police officer then I left the Division and worked in national security for a while which was really interesting. “It got to  and I wanted to come back to operational policing so I ed to Ayr as an operational inspector. “For the third time in my career, I’m back. To be a police officer, an inspector and now get the position of Area Commander in Ayr and to have lived, studied and met my we in Ayr, both personal and professional is just great. “The whole ethos of policing, for me, is community. “I am absolutely delighted to be Area Commander of South Ayrshire and I would like to thank Chief Inspector Gary I`Anson for everything that he has done for South Ayrshire and the key role that he has played over the last few years.”

title: end motoring era ayr
story: NewsEnd of a motoring era in AyrShareByStephen Houston:,  OCT News "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s the end of an era after a well-known motor garage closed its doors for the final time after eight decades in Ayr. Arnold Clark took the decision to shut the twin showrooms and workshops in the town’s Lochside. The big transporters moved in to clear the stock and the famous yellow signage was quickly taken down. The old premises in Galloway Avenue sold cars for generations and was probably best known as the home of Robert McCall Fiat and Alfa Romeo. But being stuck in the middle of housing, the old showroom has now outlived its time.. Arnold bought the dealership from Robert McCall and latterly operated a Fiat franchise. It also had the Jeep franchise for Ayr before it moved to Border Cars. The McCall family ran it for decades and built a reputation for fine service. Bob McCall began selling cars in  and had a series of franchises including Jaguar. His son Robert then took over the running of the business and was very successful selling Fiats and Alfas. Robert’s cousin Peter McCall was actually born in the house on the site that was converted into part of the garage. Customers in Galloway Avenue have been told all servicing work is going to the Ford workshop in Prestwick Road. Arnold Clark also runs separate Toyota, Vauxhall and Peugeot franchises in the town as well as a car and van hire centre. A long-time customer in Galloway Avenue said: “It is a real shame, but I guess dealerships want to be on busy roads in more modern buildings. Sadly Galloway Avenue would have needed a lot of investment and a member of staff said it simply was not in the right location any more. “Staff think the site could be flattened or put to another vehicle use.” Arnold Clark was unavailable for comment as we reached our deadline.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsMotoring NewsAlfa RomeoFiatJaguarJeepPeugeotFishingPrestwickGalloway

title: gymnastics club tries takeover council
story: NewsGymnastics club tries to takeover council activity centre in TroonMuirhead Activity Centre is the target of Dundonald Gymnastics ClubShareByStephen Houston:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA plan by a gymnastics club to take over Muirhead Activity Centre has met hostility. Secret talks have been taking place since the summer but have only just surfaced. Dundonald Gymnastics Club is ready to take control and turn the popular sports hall into a specialist centre. It would mean no more sports lets of the main hall for football, badminton and handball, the squash court would shut and the property would be shted from South Ayrshire Council ownership. Muirhead Residents and Tenants Association fired the first warning shot over the takeover. Chairman Frances Carson said: “The answer is no. If the council have pulled a fly one over this then they will never hear the end of it from this community.” Scott Telford, head coach of the gymnastics club, promised this week he will speak to the community about his ambitious plans. But Tory councillor Peter Convery slammed the secrecy, saying: “This came out of the blue to all the councillors and community and is an utter disgrace. “People at a meeting on Friday night were flabbergasted the hall could be taken out of council ownership. “The acid on the cake is the council has been speaking to the group without anyone knowing. “The council should not be treating its citizens this way.” Scott Telford said he has a full business plan for the centre and believes it can work. The club has  members and a waiting list of  more. He said the club have restricted facilities at their present base Dundonald Activity Centre, where five adults spend hours setting out and dismantling equipment. As a result they cannot develop youngsters to elite performance level and lose talented performers at an early age. Former top gymnast Scott, who lives in Muirhead, said: “The community will still get use of the centre for things like meetings and birthday parties and we would look to develop that. “There will also be the chance for the community to take part in gymnastics. “I appreciate people don’t like change but we can make this work. We could even look at parkour gymnastic sessions with teenagers on Friday night. “There is also a lot of outdoor space which we could change for other activities, depending on what the community want.” The dad first started helping at Dundonald when there were only  kids and ten mats. He added: “At the moment we get about  inquiries a week and just cannot cope. “I want to work with the Muirhead Residents and Tenants Association and want to hear all views. “We will be running a seven-day-a-week facility but it has to be financially sustainable and work with the community.” Councillor Craig Mackay said he wants full transparency when consultation starts. He said: “The onus will be on the gymnastics club to demonstrate the wider support of the community. “I am relaxed about the process and will very much wish to take on board the community’s views on this once we know the details of what is proposed. “I am concerned about how any potential transfer would impact on the use of the centre by the wide range of groups who currently use it. “The centre currently runs at a small but manageable loss and in my view any decision must be made on what is best for the community and not on the very minimal cost savings.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsGymnasticsSouth Ayrshire CouncilBadmintonTroonDundonald

story: NewsRats on loose in Ayrshire High Street as terried business owners forced to kill verminThe plague of vermin has hit Girvans Dalrymple Street and furious business owners say enough is enough.ShareCommentsByStuart Wilson:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsGus Kilgour is among those being plagued "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn army of giant RATS is stalking town centre shops and homes. The outbreak in Girvan has sparked panic among business owners battling to control the vermin. Hygiene chiefs this week slapped an emergency order on the town’s derelict former bingo hall housing the filth. And furious community leaders say the pest problem is turning their town into a no-go zone. Bill Logan, who heads Girvan’s Youth Trust, said: “We’re trying to promote ourselves as a tourist town which is open for business. “How can you do that with rats running all over the street and into shops  “I feel for businesses – it’s ridiculous they should have to put up with this.” The long-running decay of the former bingo hall and cinema was highlighted this week when rats were spotted running loose.  A number of shops in Dalrymple Street are being plagued, causing council environmental teams to swoop. Elaine Murdoch, owner of Nanettes baby shop, revealed: “Luckily I haven’t had one in yet –I did I think I’d close. “A rat ran into another shop the other day and the poor woman was hysterical. “This has been a long time coming as the state of the building is a disgrace.” South Ayrshire’s Tory council chief, Martin Dowey, is among those to have witnessed the vermin first hand. He said: “I was delivering leaflets in the town last week and one ran right in front of me. It was half the size of a cat, I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. “You have to feel for the businesses and homeowners and hopefully this is rectied as soon as possible.” A council spokesman confirmed a seven-day action order has been placed on the building.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeCommentsShow more commentsMore OnArmed forcesGirvanAyr NewsAyr

story: NewsSlow progress for new Troon mega surgeryBut work on Templehill expansion should start next yearShareByStephen Houston:,  OCT News"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNational Health top brass have been summoned to Troon to explain what is happening to expansion plans at the town’s mega surgery. Members of the public spoke at last week’s Troon Community Council –asking why there has been no obvious progress at the Templehill Surgery in nearly six month. The surgery swallowed most of the collapsed  Medical Practice, re-opening with , patients at the end of April. The Community Council has asked an NHS representative to attend their meeting next month. When Templehill took over they were to be handed around pound, by NHS Ayrshire  Arran for an extension. And partner Robbie Cumming said then it was still to be agreed wether to use a ready-made modular building or a traditional build at the back. At the time he said: “We intend to expand and develop our current premises with the addition of two or three consulting rooms, disabled access doors and a larger reception area.” A planning application has been lodged but it has not even been “validated” yet by South Ayrshire Council. Councillor Craig Mckay has quizzed Pamela Milliken, head of primary care, on the extension which had been a central plank of the transfer. Councillor Mckay said: “I welcome the Health Board’s comments which suggest that there have been no major issues following the transfers. “This is consistent with my own experience as I’ve received no recent complaints from patients. “It is also reassuring that both recipient practices have been reviewing patient records and inviting patients to attend for review appointments. “I hope this will ensure that those who were moved will continue to receive the level of care they deserve. “On the extension to the Templehill surgery, the planning application has recently been submitted but not yet validated. ““Clearly it is in the interests of all patients of that practice that the required expansion takes place, and I note that subject to there being no planning issues, work is expected to begin on site in the new year. “The extension was central to the arguments made when  Medical Practice closed, and the ball is now firmly in the Surgery’s court to deliver on this commitment.” Councillor Bob Pollock agreed the actual transition process seemed to have gone well and said: “None of the Troon Councillors have received any complaints following the merger of the surgeries, butthere are any, they should get in touch.” Ms Milliken said: “Planning permission for the work was submitted to South Ayrshire Council on Friday September . The practice is optimistic that works will commence in early Januaryplanning permission is granted.” In other NHS news, it is understood community midwives have had to change their base from the Barassie Street clinic to Prestwick. One source said: “All that is left at Barassie Street seems to be podiatry. “The community nurses have to start their sht in Prestwick before coming to Troon for their first appointment.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnTroonNHS ScotlandAyrAyr News

title: world wonder through looking glass
story: NewsWorld of wonder through the looking glass at Hendricks GinIt’s the tipple sought after and enjoyed by millions across the globe but made closer to home than you think – in the heart of Girvan.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsWhere the magic happens Hendricks Gin Palace "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“A gin made oddly”– put simply by the gin gods themselves – Hendrick’s. It’s the tipple sought after and enjoyed by millions across the globe but made closer to home than you think – in the heart of Girvan. And it’s at the newly developed multi-million pound Hendrick’s Gin Palace where the magic and wonder begins. The most signicant development since launch in , Hendrick’s Gin has been impressively expanded to meet the global demand for the ever popular drink. William Grant  Sons, the family owned independent global spirts company, has invested pound million in the glorious expansion, adding six new distillers to work under Hendrick’s Master Distiller, Lesley Gracie’s watchful eye. Innovation has always been in the brand’s DNA, echoing the ethos of Lewis Carroll who cried “curiouser and curiouser”. And it’s this spirit of invention and Alice in Wonderland-esque manner that carries through to the custom-designed complex which is encased in an enchanted walled garden, leading to a magnicent “Victorian inspired” palm house.  Surrounded by two botanical hot houses, the palm house is used to “cultivate unusual botanicals and flora from around the world”. An inner sanctum that is Lesley’s laboratory features a “curious flavour library, a lecture theatre that encourages scholarly learnings and a suitably stylish bar”. And, of course, there are two stunning new still houses. The Hendrick’s family of stills now stands at a proud six – four Bennett stills including the original antique copper pot from  and three precise replicas. The Bennett stills were handcrafted by local manufacturers Carrick Engineering and construction of the distillery was all done by local contractors and builders helping to capture the home of Hendrick’s gin right down to the foundations. The three replica stills are guarded and overlooked by a stunning stained glass ceiling – perhaps spied by Alice herself as she keeked through the looking glass. Master distiller Lesley continues that sense of wonder with every drop she makes.  Lesley said: “I’ve been distilling Hendrick’s for almost  years and during that time, my team and I have had the opportunity to explore and experiment on a small scale. “However, I’m thrilled and excited to take full advantage of our wonderful new distillery and begin working on a line of experimental liquids, some of which will hopefully blossom into future releases and potential new expressions of Hendrick’s.” Pamela Selby, the Global Brand Director for Hendrick’s added: “The Hendrick’s Gin Palace in its design and experience, is intended to inspire curiosity, open minds and serve as a  for invention. “It pulls back the curtain on the wondrous production method and showcases the many layers of Hendrick’s that it has become celebrated for, some humorous, others curiously intellectual, detailed and deeply meaningful. “It represents the confidence we have in the brand that helped to kick-start the ginaissance and leading role it has played ever since.” And with no end in sight for the beloved ginaissance – long may it live. At Alice in Wonderland’s top table it’s time for tea, but at the glorious Hendrick’s Palace it’s always gin o’clock.

title: violin-virtuosos-set-to-play-in-peebles
story: SHOWCASING equal measures of fiery Celtic fiddle and masterful classical violin, two mesmerizing performers delve deeply into the soul of ancient Scotland, Ireland, and Brittany while embracing the power of contemporary string virtuosity.Internationally acclaimed master fiddler Jamie Laval teams up with one of Britainrsquos pre-eminent classical violinists Rosemary Warren-Green for a performance of Lavals unique compositions at Eastgate Theatre on Sunday, November  at pm.Lavals bold, new works are based on traditional folk melodies and delve deeply into the soul and aesthetic of ancient Celtic music while embodying the prowess of the celebrated violinists.RosemaryWarren-Green began her career as a proteacutegeacute of Sir Yehudi Menuhin and went on to become one of Great Britains pre-eminent concert violinists.She has been a guest soloist with the Philharmonia Orchestra, Halleacute, Singapore Symphony, London Chamber Orchestra, Scottish Chamber Orchestra, and the Royal Philharmonic.Rosemary currently serves as principal viola with the London Chamber Orchestra and is a devoted educator. Her teaching posts have included the Menuhin School, the Royal College of Music, and Davidson College. Rosemary is the founder of a flourishing, London-based educational program called Music Junction, which empowers children from disparate backgrounds to explore, experience, and perform music from around the world and share this music with their communities.Jamie Laval is a critically-acclaimed performer of Celtic roots music.Praised by The Herald Scotland as a ldquocommunicator and ldquovirtuoso , Jamie calls upon his foundation in classical music to inform his singular dedication to folk music. His performance style captures the pathos and perspective of Celtic peoples, drawing upon his astonishing violinistic prowess, uncanny imitation of Highland bagpipes, innovative arrangement style, and the recounting of atmospheric mythic tales. Jamie performed for Her Majesty The Queen and presented a TEDx Talk on the value of arts and culture in our communities.The performance is a culminating event of a weekend-long symposium sponsored by Nomad Beat Community Music School.Students of the course will be invited on stage with Jamie and Rosemary to perform a specially-prepared piece during the concert.

title: galashiels-violinist-tunes-up-for-rare-local-concert
story: ONE of the most prolic and talented violin players the Borders has ever produced will play a rare concert on home soil later this month.And Gina McCormack will be ably accompanied by distinguished pianist Nigel Clayton.World class violinist Gina McCormack, who lives in Galashiels, makes frequent BBC  broadcasts, has led the Sorrel String Quartet for  years and has recorded no fewer than  CDs for the Chandos label.Nigel is professor of piano at the Royal College of Music in London.He regularly performs worldwide, both as a soloist and with chamber groups.Gina and Nigel will start the concert at Melrose Parish Church with Schubertrsquos beautul Duo in A major, followed by lsquoLa Fontaine DrsquoArethusersquo by the Polish late Romantic composer Karol Szymanowkski which depicts a fable about a young hunter who chances upon a young goddess dancing by a river.Debussyrsquos Sonata in G minor, the composerrsquos last work, comes next. A powerful piece, this is followed by Faureacutersquos Romance for violin and piano.The Melrose Music Society concert concludes with Richard Straussrsquos Sonata for violin and piano, Opus , in classical form with three movements.Ticketsfor the concert on Saturday, October  are available at the door, priced pound for non-members of the Melrose Music Society, and free for accompanied school-age children.The concert starts at .pm.

title: its-time-to-flock-to-manor-valley
story: AROUND  sheepdogs and their handlers are set to take to the ring to compete for the title of top dog next weekend.Now in its th year, the popular Manor Sheepdog Trials willon Saturday, October  to test the skill of dogs and their owners.Alongside the sheepdog trials there will be a sheep show where local farmers will show the best of their stock.The popular  mile hill run will once again take place and begins at pm.The race doesnrsquot require advance registration but runners are advised to arrive in plenty of time for the start. Previous years have seen more than  runners take part.Peebles Cycling Club will also be running a family bike ride and refreshments will be provided by the Manor Rural.The event is free and a raffle in the afternoon will raise funds for ious local charities.The sheepdog trials will begin at am and run throughout the whole day. The sheep show starts at pm.Chairman Robert Barr said: ldquoIt will be an interesting day out."The quality of the dogs coming are tremendous and of international standard."The sheep that will be shown are all local, and again, of a high standard.ldquoAt the moment the hill run route is dry underfoot and there are prizes up for grabs."But irrespective of the weather, the show will go on.

title: anne-and-dick-make-welcome-return-to-the-borders
story: TWO of the most accomplished jazz and classical musicians to to regularly take to the stage in Scotland are heading for the Borders.On Saturday, October  Anne Evans and Dick Lee will perform at Heart of Hawick for the Hawick Music Club.Fresh from recent forays into the Edinburgh Festival Fringe where Anne performed as a member of Philip Continis Be Happy Band and Dick with accordionist David Vernon, they make a welcomedown the A.In February they performed for the Hawick Music Club with Edinburghs former Poet Laureate Ron Butlin - Anne on Flute and Alto flute, Dick on clarinet, bass clarinet and recorder.It was a dynamic and engaging experience that left the audience craving more.Vanda Mercer from Hawick Music Club told us: "We were left wanting the opportunity to hear more from the musicians."Next weekend we have that chance when Anne plays for us on piano as well as the flute and Dick plays on saxophone clarinet and recorder."Classically educated having studied in Edinburgh, Vienna and London, Anne contrasts with husband Dick for original versions of many jazz classics.Their concert programme lsquocomes from a place where jazz and classical meet and mingle - Debussy and Scott Joplin in one corner and Benny Goodman and Frank Bridge in anotherrsquo.Dicks own concert compositions complete the mix-Pontefiore and Tarentella concluding the first half of the concert and Blues for Jimmy featuring in the second.These will be a special treat as his compositions have been described as truly music of the future by The Scotsman.The composition Concerto for Bagpipes and Jazz orchestra was held to great critical acclaim and though, for obvious reasons, wonrsquot be heard on the night was described by The Scotsman as a revelation.Ticketsfor non-members, priced at pound for adults and free for under s, are available from the Heart of Hawick box office on  .

title: free-tap-water-points-to-be-rolled-out-across-scotland
story: REFILL tap water points are set to be rolled out in every local authority in Scotland in the next two years.The move is part of Scottish Waters Your Water, Your Le campaign which launched earlier this year.Councils across Scotland are being consulted to identy the best locations, with the aim of having the first  installed by the end of March .Douglas Millican, Scottish Water chief executive, said: ldquoOur research shows that people feel very positively towards the quality of Scotlandrsquos tap water ndash now these state-of-the-art taps can provide access to enable water drinkers to enjoy it while on the go by carrying and using refillable bottles.Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham MSP said: ldquoBy encouraging people to top up from the tap using refillable bottles, we will help cut down on our use of plastics and promote the benefits of hydration building on Scottish Waterrsquos Your Water, Your Le campaign."For further information visit yourwateryourle.

title: graduation-day-for-langlee-toddlers
story: TWENTY-two first-time mums and their tots have graduated the Family Nurse Partnership Programme in Langlee.The first group of young mothers to complete the programme, which aims to support young mums in the first few years of their childrsquos le, were recognised at a ceremony at Langlee Community Centre.The scheme helps new mums under the age of  by offering a voluntary home visiting programme with regular specialist family nurse support from the early days of pregnancy until their child is two years old.It encourages new mums to make healthy decisions throughout pregnancies, help them improve their childrsquos health and development as well as plan their own futures and achieve their aspirations.On hand to recognise the achievements of the mothers was Acting Director of Nursing, Midwery and Acute Services at NHS Borders, Nicky Berry, who presented certicates and gts to the mums and children who were in attendance.Speaking about the event Nicky said: ldquoIt was heart-warming to see our clients brimming with pride for their children and self-confidence in their own abilities.ldquoWe were also privileged to witness the remarkable loving relationships that our clients have nurtured with their children.ldquoOur FNP toddlers showed much exuberance and joy, participating in activities at the event such as the Bookbug area for storytelling, singing nursery rhythms and playing parachutes games.ldquoWe wish our first graduates much success for their future and look forward to engaging with more young mums and their babies, as this service continues.ldquo We will begin to host celebratory graduation events twice a year, now that the service has achieved sustainability within NHS Borders.The programme, which has helped  clients to date, has run since  at NHS Borders, in partnership with NHS Lothian.Graduating FNP client, Sophie Grieve, commented: ldquoI donrsquot know where I would beit wasnrsquot for the help of [Family Nurse] Sharon and the rest of the Family Nurse Partnership.ldquoThey have helped my son and I more than they will ever know.

title: brightening-up-winter-with-galashiels-knitwear
story: A GALASHIELS knitwear company is ready for winter.And it is proving to still be top of the style stakes with the launch of its latest collection.Fashion brand Eribeacutersquos newest range of clothing and accessories has hit the shelves in time for the cold winter months.The Netherdale-based knitwear design and micro-manufacturing company sells its wares in over  stores in  countries worldwide.Now in its nd year, its knitwear is made using "hereditary skills" handed down from one generation to the next.Founder Rosemary Eribeacute said: ldquoWe love blending colours that are harmonious and scrumptious: colours that are exciting, bright, not-easy-to-forget in our fast-moving world: colours that make you look younger and feel energised.ldquoSo many people think they are not good with wearing colour, but we want to change that, and give them back confidence and that particular feeling that they might have forgotten: I will have this forever.The collection is made from natural yarns including lambswool, angora and alpaca blend, most of them spun in Scotland.The newly launched items include sweaters, cardigans, hats and scarves and take inspiration from four winter ldquocolour stories in what the company describe as a broader ldquospectrum of colours than ever.ldquoVibrant colours are included in their ldquofizz collection, ldquorich blues and touches of whites in their ldquooceans palate, ldquoochres, russets and deep greens are inspired by autumn and finally, ldquogreys whites with touches of pale hints of colours in their ldquomist collection.On the newest collection, the company said: ldquoWith inspiration from their Scottish textile heritage of Fair Isle, lace and famous tweeds, the Winter  collection is all about being unique.ldquoThe artistic blending of colours, yarns and knitting techniques offers something new.ldquoFrom lightweight lace and sporty garments in extra fine merino to the soft chunky tactile handknit textures, there is a knit for all occasions.

title: rural-roads-to-benefit-from-900000-strengthening-project
story: THREE roads south of Hawick are set for major improvements.The rural roads will benefit from a total of pound, awarded by the Strategic Timber Transport Fund alongside pound, of investment from Scottish Borders Council.The B near Shankend Quarry will be strengthened and have edges reconstructed following years of wear and tear.The B near Newcastleton will be strengthened at two section - around Dawstonburn and also at Kirndean.And the D  Roberton to Craik road will be strengthened as well as drainage and passing place improvements, and edge widening.Councillor Gordon Edgar, SBCrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoThis allocation from the Strategic Timber Transport Fund, alongside investment from our own budgets, will greatly improve the rural roads identied as requiring attention."We recognise the importance of the road network to rural communities in terms of the local economy and employment, so this pound, investment is welcomed and compliments the additional pound.million being spent on resurfacing across the Borders in this financial year.The Strategic Timber Transport Fund was set up by the Scottish Government in  in recognition of the challenge faced in getting timber to market.It is administered by Forestry Commission Scotland in order to facilitate the sustainable transport of timber in rural areas of Scotland for the benefit of local communities and the environment, maximising the value of monies available through innovative projects and partnerships.

title: final-chance-to-pick-the-pet-idol-winner
story: Itrsquos the final countdown in our fantastic Pet Idol competition!The lucky top  pets who have made it through to the last round have been revealed.Theyrsquore competing to be crowned our  Pet Idol and win the pound cash prize.And the winner will be decided by you, readers of the Borderand Peeblesshire News.Yoursquoll find the a voting token on the inside back page of this weeks paper, so make sure you get voting now.Remember you can enclose multiple tokens in one envelope to save on postage.You have until noon on Friday, October  to vote for your winner and wersquoll announce our  Pet Idol shortly after then.Donrsquot delay ndash vote for your winning Pet Idol today!

title: bag-it-and-bin-it-message
story: DOG owners in the Borders are being urged to lsquoBag it and bin itrsquo following a warning about the health risks of dog fouling.As part of the Scottish Borders Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos Healthy Lives Week, the Scottish Borders Council has highlighted the health risks of failing to pick up after your dog.Councillor Sandy Aitchison , who is executive member for neighbourhoods and locality services, said: ldquoThe vast majority of dog owners are responsible, but a small minority cause misery for their neighbours and their local communities by refusing to pick up behind their dog.ldquoIt is absolutely unacceptable and the health risks of dog faeces are well documented. By leaving it on the pavement, in parks and on sports pitches these people are putting the health of the public, particularly children at serious risk."The health risk posed comes from roundworm eggs which may be deposited in dog faeces. These become infectious after about three weeks and can remain so for up to two years. Anyone, but particularly children, playing near to the ground run the risk of picking up and swallowing the eggs.These roundworm parasites can cause toxocaral infection, symptoms of which range from aches, dizziness and nausea, to asthma and pneumonia. In rare cases, eye disease and loss of vision can be caused when the toxocara larva passes through the eye.Cllr Aitchison added: ldquoOur message is clear ndash play #yourpart and bag it and bin it. It is as simple as that.ldquoOur communities recognise this as a serious issue and it is also important to work with us to report problem areas and give us information which will help us tackle this real hazard to health and quality of le.The councilrsquos Responsible Dog Ownership Strategy aims to change peoplersquos behaviour to dog fouling and remind owners of their social and legal responsibilities.As part of the strategy, posters and pavement stencils can be requested by members of the public to be placed in areas where dog fouling is an issue.Communities can also sign up to SBCrsquos Green Dog Walker Scheme, which aims to change attitudes towards dog fouling.The council has also reminded members of the public to report incidents of dog fouling and to provide as many details as possible such as the exact location, the time when the dog fouling takes place and a description of the owner and their dog.Information can be provided anonymously and there is no need to provide further evidence at a later date.For more information on the strategy visit www.scotborders.gov.uk dogfouling or to report dog fouling phone   .

title: pupils-explore-the-appliance-of-science
story: PRIMARY pupils from Tweeddale got to grips with all things science at a hands-on workshop at the Eastgate Theatre.Youngsters joined scientists, engineers, and maths professionals during the second of this yearrsquos school science days.Science workshop days have been an annual feature of the Eastgate programme for more than a decade, with children learning about everything from the power of negative numbers to extracting DNA from strawberries.This year artist and glassblower Dr Ayako Tani joined Dr Roger Hillrsquos Terric Technology workshop where she invited pupils to explore the intriguing concept of the ship in a bottle.A selection of ships in bottles made in Sunderland in the s were displayed and Dr Tani showed her own extra-large example called the City of Adelaide.The final workshop culminated in a talk delivered by Professor Lesley Yellowlees CBE who discussed all aspects of renewable energy from the perspectives of science, engineering, economic, social and policy.See this weeks Peeblesshire News for our picture special from the event

title: budding-designers-asked-to-provide-cover
story: KIDS Innerleithen Youth Theatre is calling all artists across Tweeddale to get creative and design the programme cover for their debut show next month.The cast have been rehearsing for months in preparation for their performance of Annie Jnr at the Memorial Hall in November.The organisation was formed after members of Innerleithen District Operatic Society recognised the need to create a theatre group for young thespians locally.Committee members felt that, as it is a childrenrsquos show, it would be fitting to feature a childrsquos design on the cover of the programme.President of IDOS Nicola Watt, said: ldquoWe are very proud of how hard the cast of KIYT have worked since its inception, but especially in the months leading up to this, their first full production.ldquoWe thought a programme cover competition would help get other children involved and of course, help spread the word about this fabulous show and make it a huge success to reward all the childrenrsquos efforts.Both primary and secondary aged children across Tweeddale and Peeblesshire are being invited to design a cover with whatever they feel best represents the show.The showrsquos title does not need to be included as this will already be produced on the cover, however artwork must be within an area of cm x cm.While the winning design will feature on the programme, it is hoped that all entries will be displayed in the Memorial Hall during the shows which will run on November -.Designs must be submitted by October  by post to KIYT Cover Competition, Piccadilly,  High Street, Innerleithen, EH HD, or scanned and emailed to president@idaos.or.ukTicketsfor the show are now available for purchase from the Thrt Shop in Innerleithen, www.idas.org.uk booking@idaos.org.uk, Facebook inneropera, or by phoning   .

title: eastgate-theatre-is-telling-tales
story: A PEEBLES theatre is taking to the road this autumn to deliver a series of storytelling events.Eastgate Theatre will be travelling to some unexpected and beautul Borders locations as part of its Wild Little Stories series which promises songs, tunes, films and, of course, stories.The events are being run as part of the  Scottish International Storytelling Festival with the first event taking place at St Ronanrsquos Wells, Innerleithen, on Friday, October , -pm.Storyteller and clarsach player Heather Yule will weave stories and music into a fun, family afternoon before leading a workshop to create new stories inspired by St Ronanrsquos Wells and the abundant plants and animals that grow and live beside it.On Saturday, October , Wild Little Stories moves on to Kailzie Gardens, where storyteller and artist Mary Kenny will lead a walk through the grounds and relay stories including tales of the fairy realm, selkies, giants and ghosts. The event runs from -pm.The final, Halloween-themed Wild Little Stories takes place at Whitmuir Farm near Lamancha on Wednesday, October , .-.pm. Led by storyteller Lea Taylor, the event will include scary stories, a pumpkin carving workshop and a special Halloween pumpkin parade.Ticketsare pound, pound for under s and pound for a family of four , available from Box Office on   or online at www.eastgatearts

title: fox-hunting-trial-put-on-hold-for-two-months
story: THE trial of two huntsmen accused of ignoring Scotlands fox hunting legislation has been adjourned for two months.Three days of evidence have already been heard at Jedburgh Sherf Court in the case of -year-old Timothy Allen and Shaun Anderson, , both from the Buccleuch Hunt.They are accused of deliberately hunting a fox with a pack of dogs at Whitton Farm, near Morebattle, on December  last year in breach of the Protection of Wild Mammals.Both men have pleaded not guilty to the charge.On day three of the trial, police firearms expert Inspector Keith Warhurst referred to video evidence supplied by the League Against Cruel Sports.He felt there was a sufficient gap from the fox being flushed from cover to stop the hounds from pursuing it.The law prevents the dogs from pursuing the fox which should be dispatched with a gun after being flushed from cover.The trial has now been adjourned until December .Another four days have been set aside to hear further evidence in the case.

title: new-club-feeling-anything-but-blue
story: A NEW monthly Borders blues club has hit the high notes following a successful launch last week.Launched by Paul Burnett, lead singer with local band Unfinished Business, the Borders Blues Clubrsquos inaugural night took place on October  at the Vale Club Innerleithen.Showcasing two blues groups, the club hosted performances from Glasgow band Used Blues and Newcastle native Robbie Reay.The club has been launched in collaboration with The Vale Club Innerleithen, with support from The Falkirk and Stirling Blues Club, and aims to promote accessible and affordable blues music.Ticketsfor the club nights are pound and the events are being run on a not-for-profit basis, with all proceeds from ticket sales going directly to the artists.The club will run on the first Friday of every month and each show will feature two quality blues acts.The next event will take place on November  and will feature performances from The Blue Hyenas as well as Reece Hillis and John Boos.For more details on upcoming events visit The Borders Blues Club on Facebook.

title: kelso-hosts-singer-and-activist-peggy-seeger
story: Folk fans are invited to Kelsorsquos Tait Hall as singer and activist Peggy Seeger takes to the stage for what promises to be a memorable performance.The show on November  at .pm is billed as An Evening of Song and Conversation and will feature performances from Peggy, now in her s, along with her two sons Calum and Neil.Peggyrsquos new show will welcome and encourage audience participation as she performs some of the songs that have meant the most to her over the years.Following the paperback publication of her award-winning memoir The First Time Ever last month, Peggy will also be reading from the book as well as performing renditions of her husband Ewan MacCollrsquos most treasured songs.Becki Hodgson, Live Borders rural touring development officer, said: ldquoThis is a wonderful opportunity to catch this inspirational and iconic folk musician as she visits the Scottish Borders.Expect anecdotes, delivered with wry humour and an entertaining insight into the remarkable le of one of the best loved lsquoqueens of folkrsquo.Ticketscost pound-pound. Visit www.liveborders.org.uk

title: galashiels-pensioner-cleared-of-flashing-offence
story: A GALASHIELS pensioner accused of exposing himself to two women has had the case against him deserted at Selkirk Sherf Court.Seventy three year old Robert Coltherd had been charged with committing the offence at his home in Market Street on July .It was alleged he intentionally exposed his genitals in a sexual manner to the two women with the intention they would see them by standing in the common stair naked and speaking to them.He was also charged with making a sexual remark to one of the women between January , , and December , .But when the case called at Selkirk Sherf Court the Crown announced they were deserting the case.

title: weekend-of-stories-opens-new-chapter-for-house-built-on-words
story: LITERARY sessions are set toto their rightful place later this month.In the early th century, the centre of the British literary world was not to be found amongst the publishing houses of London or Edinburgh or in the fashionable salons of Mayfair or Piccadilly.It stood on the banks of the Tweed.Abbotsford was the house built on words, the home of the first worldwide bestselling author, Sir Walter Scott, and it was a magnet and a mecca for writers, artists and great intellectuals.William Wordsworth, Lord Byron, JMW Turner, Sir Humphrey Davy and many others basked in the glow of Scottrsquos reputation and the warmth of his fabled hospitality.And even after his death in , Abbotsford became a shrine, attracting pilgrims such as Charlotte Bronte and Charles Dickens.Five years ago, the house was gloriously restored, a wonderful new visitor centre built and now with the launch of the Abbotsford Literary Sessions, old traditions are about to be revived.Writers are coming back to Scottrsquos house.Launching on October  and , four very dferent authors will discuss their new books in Ochiltreersquos Cafeacute.In association with Baillie Gford and the Abbotsford Trust, Paula Ogilvie and Alistair Moffat have compiled a programme - two double bills over two evenings.At pm on the Saturday Simon Jenkins, former editor of The Times and bestselling author, will talk about A Short History of Europe ndash from Pericles to Putin.Europe has for two millennia been a remarkably successful continent. Yet, despite the importance of its politics, economy and culture, there has not been ndash until now ndash a concise book to tell this story.Simon has written a gripping account of its evolution ndash a story that twists and turns from Greece and Rome to the Second World War and up to the present day.Also on the Saturday Ben Macintyre will talk about his new book, The Spy and the Traitor.Described by the master of the fictional genre, John le Carreacute, as lsquothe best true spy story I have ever readrsquo, the thrilling cold war tale is simply astonishing.This fascinating account reveals the amazing story of Britainrsquos most successful Russian agent and is a tale of espionage and betrayal which changed the course of the Cold War.At pm on the Sunday, Penny Junor will offer a lighter touch with her All the Queenrsquos Corgis.It is an affectionate and entertaining look at the relationship Elizabeth II has with her most faithful companions. She looks at the dogs that have been bred, owned by and given to the Queen throughout her le, revealing a very private side that is seldom seen.Neuroscientist Joseph Jebelli will complete the Abbotsford Sessions with a talk about his In Pursuit of Memory ndash The Fight Against Alzheimerrsquos.This wonderful, moving book unpacks the facts and realities behind a more common killer than cancer, and explores the past, present and future of Alzheimerrsquos disease starting from the very beginning. It is a story as riveting as a detective novel.A rich, ied programme - exactly the sort of thing that would have made Sir Walter smile.The Abbotsford Literary Sessions in association with Baillie Gford take place at Abbotsford Visitor Centre on Saturday, October  with Simon Jenkinsand Ben Macintyre , and Sunday, October  with Penny Junorand Joseph Jebelli .Ticketsavailable from www.litsessions and   .

title: borders-chapter-of-book-week-scotland-announced
story: A WEEK of literary events has been announced in the Borders as part of Book Week Scotland .Between November  and  the Scottish Book Trust is set to deliver hundreds of free events and activities, funded by Scottish Library and Information Council, throughout Scotland.Crime writer Aline Templeton will visit Melrose Library on November  from pm to pm to talk about her journey from a six-year-old aspiring writer to the author of The Third Sin, the latest title in her popular Galloway-based crime fiction series.Borders writer Jules Horne will visit Hawick Library on November  and  from .pm to .pm to present a spoken word performance of modern Border ballads and nanonovels in Scots and English.She will be accompanied by stand-up cello and loop station and the performance will feature the Borders Heritage Festival Commission Three Border Songs and a touch of Borders Gothic.Local writer Margaret Skea will give an illustrated presentation on her -mile solo research trip to the former German Democratic Republic in search of Katharina von Bora - the nun who became the we of the controversial reformer Martin Luther.Margaret will also discuss her award-winning book that was a result of this search, Katharina: Deliverance, at the event at Galashiels Library on November  from .pm and .pm.Writers interested in self-publishing are being encouraged to attend CABN Indie Author Gathering on November , am - pm, at Galashiels Library.Promising an insight into the world of self-publishing, the event will provide an opportunity to meet like-minded writers, show and sell books, share information, and learn from other authors experiences.Culture Secretary Fiona Hyslop said: ldquoAs a le-long and avid reader, I know that therersquos no greater pleasure than losing yourself in the magic of a book.ldquoThatrsquos why I welcome this fantastic launch of  Book Week Scotland programme, a flagship event of Scotlandrsquos culture sector celebrating books, reading and Scotlandrsquos rich literary history and dedicated this year to exploring the theme of lsquoRebelrsquo.The seventh national celebration of books and reading was launched in Edinburgh where drag queen and Book Week Scotland ambassador, Nancy Clench, and bestselling author Claire Askew, posed with copies of the Rebel book, which features a story from Nancy, as well as others submitted from the public.Marc Lambert, CEO of Scottish Book Trust, said: ldquoWersquore delighted to present another packed programme for Book Week Scotland, our national celebration of reading and writing.ldquoAfter listening to feedback, Scottish Book Trust is pleased to make , copies of the Rebel book available to the public.ldquoMany thanks to our partners and funders for making this programme possible, and we hope everyone joins us for Book Week Scotland, whether at a physical event, or by taking part in our Digital Festival.Erin McElhinney, Literature Officer, Creative Scotland, commented: ldquoScottish Book Trust have produced a programme that offers a whole host of routes into reading and writing, offering a cause to the rebel in all of us.ldquoItrsquos a week to celebrate new partnerships and connections, between organisations and the public, between digital and the book ndash and an invitation to challenge our own boundaries around reading.For information on events visit https:bookweekscotlandevents

title: plans-submitted-for-melrose-housing-development
story: FINALISED plans for a major housing development on the lower slopes of the Eildons have been submitted with the local authority.Rural Renaissance Ltd want to develop a . acre site next to Dingleton Road in Melrose.Initial proposals for  properties have been reduced to  detached and semi-detached three-, four-, and five-bedroom houses following a public consultation exercise and meetings with Scottish Borders Councils planners.The full application includes a new access across the Muirhouse Burn as well as new roadways and landscaping.All of the new properties will be built around The Croft, which currently operates as a childrens nursery.The full application will be considered by Scottish Borders Council over the coming months.

title: two-day-trial-scheduled-for-nursery-workers-accused-of-cruelty
story: TWO days have been set aside later this month for the trial of two nursery workers accused of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner to children in their care.Nicola Jeffrey, who is , and -year-old Teresa Renton are alleged to have committed the offence on ious occasions between January , , and August ,  at Little Reivers Nursery in Duns, which has since closed.They both pleaded not guilty at Jedburgh Sherf Court to a charge of shouting, forcibly dragging children about and lting them off the floor by the arm.They are also accused of locking children inside cupboards and refusing to let them out, making offensive and abusive comments towards and about young children and behaving in an aggressive, threatening and abusive manner.Jeffrey is further alleged to have seized hold of the arm of an injured child who was receiving treatment from a colleague and it was later ascertained the arm had sustained two fractures.Jeffrey is also said to changed the nappy of a child in a public place in view of the public on a concrete floor without using any mat.Renton of Ainslie Terrace and Jeffrey of Rachel Drive, both Duns, pleaded not guilty to the charge.The trial is scheduled to take place at Jedburgh Sherf Court on October  and .

title: selkirk-and-kelso-pupils-prepare-for-wee-sleep-out
story: THE Borders Wee Sleep Out next month has secured the support of local entertainers, bus companies and the Quarriers Resilience for Wellbeing service.It is anticipated that several hundred youngsters aged eight to  will bed down for the night in sleeping bags at Kelsorsquos Springwood Park hall - with the heating off - as part of a nationwide event to raise money and awareness of the Social Bite campaign to end homelessness. After the success of the national Sleep in the Park last year, Wee Sleep Outs are being held across the country.And the Borders Union Agricultural Society Showground is the focus for the big Borders event on Saturday, November .Pupils from Selkirk High have joined their counterparts from Kelso High in organising the Borders Wee Sleep Out.And free bus travel is being provided to Springwood from Melrose, Galashiels, Earlston and Hawick as well as Selkirk.Kelso pupil Olivia Ferguson, who came up with the idea for the Springwood event, told us: ldquoIt is taking off with so many people coming forward to support and lots of schools talking about it now which is fantastic."But schools still need to sign up before the October  deadline."It was great to get the support and enthusiasm from Selkirk High staff and students, and the wonderful Quarriers staff now supporting students in Borders schools."That means we will have plenty of PVG-disclosed adults at the event, along with teachers who have been brilliant in coming forward to offer their support."During the Wee Sleep Out local singer-songwriter Erin Highton will be performing, along with the popular M-Pulsive Dancers and DJ Pries.Presenters from Radio Borders will also take to the Springwood Park stage.And organisers hope to announce more entertainment acts in the coming weeks.Olivia also revealed: "Robertsonrsquos Buses have offered to pick up people from across all the Berwickshire school areas, Borders Buses are going to run buses from Galashiels, Selkirk and Hawick, passing through Jedburgh, and Austin Travel are picking up in Earlston and Melrose."And their brilliant drivers are going to be there at .am on Sunday morning to take everyone back to their schools!"Thatrsquos huge and wersquod like to thank them, the Border Union Agricultural Society, Kelso Laddies Association, teachers and our entertainers for getting behind the event."Wersquore also speaking to catering companies and would like to hear from anyone who wants to support our part in the campaign to end homelessness.The event is open to all school-children aged eight years old and over, although schools and youth organisations will need a PVG-disclosed adult to sign their group up on the Social Bite website - www.sleepinthepark wee-sleep-out - before October .The Scottish Government last week pledged pound.m to Social Bitersquos campaign.The charityrsquos co-founder Alice Thompson is delighted that further support is coming from across the country - including the Borders.She stated: ldquoThe Borders has really taken to Livvyrsquos Wee Sleep Out in Kelso and wersquore supporting her and the Kelso and Selkirk schools to attract as many young people as possible."The venue can take up to  so there is plenty of space for those who want to spend a night in their sleeping bags supporting our campaign to end homelessness."But get signed up before the deadline.

title: german-archaeologists-uncover-the-secrets-of-torwodlee-and-trimontium
story: A MAJOR survey by German archaeologists has uncovered important fresh finds on historic sites near Melrose and Galashiels.Last week members of the German Archaeological Institute helped carry out the largest single geophysical survey ever performed in the Scottish Borders at Trimontium.And they also undertook extensive work at Torwoodlee.The week-long expedition, which was co-sponsored by the Trimontium Trust and the German government, was led by RGKs Dr Ruth Beusing.Along with her team important new geophysical discoveries were made at and around the hillfort at Torwoodlee.And the survey of Trimontium has produced never before seen details of the site.Dr John Reid, chair of The Trimontium Trust, told the Border : "This has been a fantastic once in a letime collaboration with such a well-organised and efficient team."We have been privileged to have the full resources of the RGK behind this project which has revealed the site in astonishing detail."The team has worked from dawn until dusk to create what represents the most detailed images ever produced of a Roman fort in Scotland."Many new discoveries have been made which will be revealed over the next couple of months as Dr Beusing and her team process the terabytes of data on theirto Frankfurt."The Trimontium Trust is hugely grateful to Mr James Pringle at Torwoodlee and Mr Paul Rooney at Newstead for their generous permission to investigate the sites."It has moved forward our thinking on a number of key aspects of the Roman occupation."The project was aimed at investigating the possible relationship between the invading Roman forces of Trimontium and the indigenous population living at the Torwoodlee hillfort.James Pringle, owner of Torwoodlee, told us: "The more we can discover about our past and our history, the more we will be able to understand what has made us the people we now are."Perhaps that will help us to plot a path through the future with greater and better vision for our communitys well-being."Dr Beusing and her team willto Torwoodlee next year to carry out further survey work.And in the coming weeks the Trimontium Trust will unveil details of the discoveries made on the Roman site near Newstead.Dr Christopher Bowles from Scottish Borders Council believes the week-long survey is vitally important for helping to understand our local history - and it carries on the work of other great archaeologists.He said: "In the early part of the th century two brothers from Melrose, James and Alexander Curle, revolutionised archaeology not just in Scotland, but across northern Europe.But their interests stayed local."James excavated the now famous Roman fort of Trimontium at Newstead, and helped the Galashiels Ramblers Club excavate the mysterious site of Torwoodlee Broch."Just over  years later the Curle brothers influence on Scottish archaeology is still strong, and its only fitting that following in their footsteps the Trimontium Trust, along with the German Archaeological Institute, have provided exciting new insights into both Trimontium and Torwoodlee Broch using cutting edge geophysical techniques."This is no doubt the beginnings of a new revolution in our understanding of the Borders rich archaeological heritage that will still be celebrated  years from now."

title: adam-has-some-food-for-thought-for-borders-communities
story: A PEEBLES gardener is urging Borderers to follow his lead and set up more Food Communities in the area.Adam Skelton recently transformed land behind the townrsquos old courthouse into a public garden, where locals can grow their own produce.And now he wants to see more green-fingered people getting stuck in across the region. The -year-old told us: ldquoI was first introduced to gardening by my parents who were growing all sorts of fruit and vegetables whilst I was at school.ldquoI remember really enjoying picking fresh fruit in the garden. And I loved eating my mumrsquos crumbles, cakes and pies that she made with them.ldquoThe food I grew up eating was amazing ndash served after lots of preparation, and usually using fresh home-grown ingredients. Food and community are two of the most fundamental things to me.ldquoAnd theyrsquore two things that we should be doing so much better. Food Communities is essentially about communities coming together to produce their own food. My aim is to inspire collaboration. If lots of people get involved we can be enjoying the freshest, tastiest, healthiest, most eco-friendly, truly local food and saving lots of money.Adam has helped to transform a number gardens as part of the Food Communities scheme ndash a social enterprise run by volunteers.He added: ldquoItrsquos relatively easy to begin growing for yourself ndash from the tiniest garden to someone who has a spare patch of land and would just like a helping hand to turn it into a burgeoning community garden.ldquoItrsquos a common misconception that growing your own food is too much work and takes too much time it actually doesnrsquot need much of either ndash as long as you keep going with it regularly, and share the workload.ldquoFood Communities spotlights the endless amazing things going on every day in our communities and provides a  for neighbours, young and old, to work together with a common purpose. Because we pay no rent or wages and do and acquire everything for free, we have a resilient long-term plan and a template that we aim to offer to local communities all across Scotland.A Facebook group has been set up to offer advice to people thinking about getting involved and monthly meet-ups also take place.Adam added: ldquoWe usually have an expert guest speaker talking to us about food, community and environment related topics. Group members also regularly swap and share food, tools, materials, resources, seeds, plants, knowledge, and skills.For more information, visit: www.facebook communitiesfood

title: aussies-say-good-on-ya-to-melrosian-honesty
story: MELROSE isnrsquot just the best place to live in Scotland.It is also the most honest, according to two Australian tourists.The couple from Down Under were sampling the historical delights of the town recently.But Afton Johnston and her husbandrsquos dream trip turned into a nightmare when they left their camera, full of holiday memories, in Market Square.The couple had driven almost  miles north before realising.But, thanks to staff at a Melrose cafe, the Melbourne pair can enjoy leafing through their snaps once again.Afton told the Border : ldquoWe discovered later that I had left my camera on a seat in the square.ldquoAfter leaving the square I went shopping in Boots the chemist. And from Melrose we drove to Falkirk, where I discovered my camera containing a monthrsquos holiday photos was missing.ldquoAt the Falkirk Wheel Visitor Centre they made some calls for me. The chemist suggested that we ring the cafe in front of the seat. They rang Rhymers Fayre and the gentleman there went out into the street to check.ldquoMy camera was still on the seat after two hours, we drove to Melrose and collected it. Thank you to the helpful Melrose folk.The town was named the best place to live in Scotland, by the Sunday Times back in March.

title: washington-post-publishes-new-khashoggi-column
story: The Washington Post has published a new column by missing Saudi writer Jamal Khashoggi in which he warns that governments in the Middle East ldquohave been given free rein to continue silencing the media at an increasing rate.The Post published the column on Wednesday, more than two weeks after Mr Khashoggi was last seen entering the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul and only hours after a gruesome account in Turkeyrsquos Yeni Safak newspaper alleged that Saudi officials cut off Mr Khashoggirsquos fingers and then decapitated him inside the consulate while his fiancee waited outside.The Saudi government, including Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has denied any involvement.In a note affixed to the top of the column, Post Global Opinions editor Karen Attiah said she received the essay from Mr Khashoggirsquos translator and assistant a day after he was reported missing.Mr Khashoggi first began writing for the Postrsquos opinion section in September , and his columns criticised the prince and the direction of the Saudi kingdom.In print tomorrow, Jamal Khashoggis final column: "What the Arab world needs most is free expression" https:t.co yyBJJENvpic BEMjvxKpmdash Washington PostOctober , In the op-ed, titled ldquoJamal Khashoggi: What the Arab world needs most is free expression, Mr Khashoggi recounted the imprisonment of a prominent writer who spoke against the Saudi establishment, and cited an incident in which the Egyptian government seized control of a newspaper.ldquoThese actions no longer carry the consequence of a backlash from the international community. Instead, these actions may trigger condemnation quickly followed by silence, he wrote.ldquoAs a result, Arab governments have been given free rein to continue silencing the media at an increasing rate, Khashoggi wrote.US president Donald Trump, who initially came out hard on the Saudis over the disappearance but since has backed off, said on Wednesday that the US wanted Turkey to turn over any audio or video recording it had of Mr Khashoggirsquos alleged killing ldquo it exists.He has recently suggested that the global community had jumped to conclusions that Saudi Arabia was behind Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance.In the column, Mr Khashoggi, a Saudi citizen who went into self-imposed exile in the US over the rise of the crown prince, also discussed the practice of Middle Eastern governments blocking internet access to control tightly the information their citizens can see.Turkish forensic officers have been at the Saudi consulate to conduct a new search ldquoThe Arab world is facing its own version of an Iron Curtain, imposed not by external actors but through domestic forces vying for power, Mr Khashoggi wrote.He praised the Post for translating many of his columns from English into Arabic and said it was important for Middle Easterners to be able to read about democracy in the West.He also said it was critical that Arab voices have a  on which to be heard.ldquoWe suffer from poverty, mismanagement and poor education, Mr Khashoggi wrote.ldquoThrough the creation of an independent international forum, isolated from the influence of nationalist governments spreading hate through propaganda, ordinary people in the Arab world would be able to address the structural problems their societies face.The Post initially held off on publishing the column amid hope for Mr Khashoggirsquos , Ms Attiah said. But, she wrote, ldquoNow I have to accept: That is not going to happen.She ended her note: ldquoThis column perfectly captures his commitment and passion for freedom in the Arab world. A freedom he apparently gave his le for. I will be forever grateful he chose The Post as his final journalistic home one year ago and gave us the chance to work together..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Washington Post publishes new Khashoggi column
